direction.raw_text: (distractedly) Nobody. PUPKIN carefully places himself near the door, a step or two away from the other professionals.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to SIDNEY) I got Mr. Raf Vallone outside 21.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to SIDNEY about PUPKIN) He'd never tell you anyway, Sidney.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I got him again at the Pierre at four o'clock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be a dear, Mae. I don't happen to have Mr. Vallone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what I want for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I have only six Barbra's left. You know how difficult she is to work with.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't have her even once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to MAE) Maybe Rupert would help you. PUPKIN shoots a hostile glance back at CELESTE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you do that, Rupert? You don't feel about Barbra the way I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll give you Mr. Burt Reynolds too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (needling RUPERT) Look, Sidney, Rupert doesn't do that sort of thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about it, Rupert?   I'll give you whoever you want. SIDNEY starts pulling little white cards out of his paper bag and reading them off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Rodney    Dangerfield ... Richard Harris    ... Liza Minelli ... and she's    not so easy to work with either    ... Louise Lasser!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: You're wasting your time. PUPKIN has been trying to remain apart from the other three. Finally he turns to SIDNEY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, Sidney. I'm just not interested. This isn't my whole life, you know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that supposed to mean -- that it's my whole life, or Sidney's or Mae's?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is so my whole life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut up, Mae. What about your mother? Isn't she part of your life?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's her whole life too. The show breaks. The doors swing open and people pour out. The crowd around the backstage door swells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the crowd) If you want Jerry's autograph, give me your piece of paper and I'll send it backstage. A number of people in the crowd hand in pieces of paper. PUPKIN is standing next to a young couple, about college age. The YOUNG GIRL has just sent in her paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the GIRL) What are you going to do with Jerry's autograph?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. Maybe I'll sell it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll tell you what she's going to do with it. She's going to pin it on her bulletin board and have an orgasm. The YOUNG GIRL laughs unself-consciously.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : LANGFORD's limousine waits directly in front of the stage door. MAE has engaged the CHAUFFEUR who stands at the door of the car in conversation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (wearily) No, Mae.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't mean now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Mae.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll get right out. The CHAUFFEUR, smiling, shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : A plain-looking GIRL in a black raincoat and black, floppy hat stands on the street side of the limousine, carefully watching MAE and the CHAUFFEUR talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: But I've never been in one. We hear a cry as a celebrity emerges from the backstage door. MAE turns and goes back towards the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : The POLICEMAN is handing out the autographs. Suddenly LANGFORD emerges, flanked by three PAGES, husky young men in their early twenties dressed in theater uniforms. There is screaming and some yelling of LANGFORD's name. LANGFORD pays no attention. Smiling nervously, he makes his way towards the limousine. The CHAUFFEUR stands at the rear of the car, holding the door. LANGFORD enters the car and then suddenly springs back. The GIRL in the black raincoat and black hat has hidden herself in the back seat of the limousine. The three PAGES, who have already turned and headed back toward the theater, hear the commotion and swing around. The GIRL, who we shall come to know as MARSHA, hides herself in the far end of the limo, so two of the PAGES go around to the far side of the car and start pulling her out while the third PAGE moves into the limo from the street side. She fights like a wildcat, but the PAGES slowly    manage to drag her out. During the struggle, LANGFORD     stands amid the crowd, a bit shaken. PUPKIN stands next to     him, staring at him. When finally catches LANGFORD's eye,    PUPKIN smiles pleasantly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (to LANGFORD who barely listens) How the hell did that girl get in there? Jesus, they certainly don't give you very good protection, do they? LANGFORD says nothing, glancing nervously at PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at you here. Who the hell is watching you? Any one of these freaks could just walk right up to you and do whatever he wants. A couple YOUNG GIRLS are pressing against LANGFORD.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Jerry. How can we get to talk to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a minute. This is crazy. PUPKIN straightens up for action.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (yelling at the crowd) Okay! Stand back! PUPKIN wades through the crowd towards the limousine, pushing SIDNEY and MAE among others out of the way. LANGFORD follows in the path PUPKIN is clearing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't you hear me?!?    Come on, people, have a heart. The PAGES have succeeded in pulling the GIRL out of the far door of the limo just as PUPKIN and LANGFORD arrive at the near door. The CHAUFFEUR has been blocked by the crowd from opening the door so PUPKIN opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks.   Thanks very much. PUPKIN stares at LANGFORD for a moment and then slides into the limo next to him, closing the door behind him. 2   INT:   LIMO - NIGHT PUPKIN I hate to bother you like this, Jerry, but could I speak to you for a minute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to but ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you're a busy man. I promise not to take very long, really. But I need your advice. PUPKIN looks down at his hand which has been badly scratched.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't have a handkerchief, do you? Jesus, these people will kill you for a cufflink. LANGFORD hands him a monogrammed handkerchief, then checks his watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks. If you have to be somewhere, I don't mind talking as we drive. You can drop me off anywhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, but I've got a strict rule never to ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I put myself on the line for you, Jerry. Reluctantly, LANGFORD signals with his head to his CHAUFFEUR to start moving. As the car moves through New York traffic, PUPKIN and LANGFORD talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, Jerry. I'm grateful for this chance to talk to you ... I hope I'm not boring you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll let you know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really? Fine. I'm      Rupert Pupkin, Jerry. I know that the name    itself doesn't mean very much to you but    it means an awful lot to me, believe me.     Maybe you've seen me outside your show and wondered who I am. Well, right now, I'm in communications but, by nature, I'm a stand-up comedian. I know what you're thinking -- 'oh no. Not another one.' And I wouldn't take up even one minute of your time if I wasn't absolutely convinced of my talent. I'm really good, Jerry, believe me, I'm dynamite. Now you're probably wondering if I'm so good why haven't you caught my act somewhere, right?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stand back!    (To LANGFORD)   Go ahead, Jerry. LANGFORD slips in quickly. He looks up at PUPKIN who is holding the door, smiling pleasantly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Well, up to now, I've been biding my time, developing my act slowly and carefully so that when my big break finally comes, I'm ready -- like you were that night Paar got sick and you sat in for him. I was there that night, in the theater. That was the most important night of my life, until tonight, of course. PUPKIN fishes a cigarette case out of his jacket pocket, flips it open and offers one to LANGFORD.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No thanks.   I don't smoke. PUPKIN returns the pack to his pocket.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Me neither. I just carry them as a courtesy. How about a cough drop?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling indulgently) No thanks. I don't cough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I try not to but sometimes, you know ... Am I making any sense?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) Go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that night you did Paar, I walked out of the theater like I was in a dream. All of a sudden, I knew what I wanted. I started catching your guest appearances on Sullivan and taping them and, when you got your own show, it got to be a kind of regular thing. I studied how you built to your one-liners, nice and relaxed like you were chatting, and how you delivered the jokes without leaning too much on them, without saying "here's the punchline, folks." And I watched the way you played off dead audiences, how you let those long silences build until people couldn't stand it and then the way you got them off the hook with that slow smile. You were my college of comedy, Jerry, like a kind of teacher, a friend. I know it sounds crazy, but when you watch someone every night ... But that's all in the past. What I'm trying to say is this. I'm ready now. I've finished the course. And I'm thinking as we sit here talking "Is this it? Is this that one big break?" Is it, Jerry? There is a long pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jerry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look ... er ... what was the name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Rupert, Jerry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, Rupert. I know what you're saying. But things don't work that way. You can't just walk onto a network show without any experience. You've got to start at the bottom ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But that's where I am!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've got to work your way up, learn your trade in front of live audiences, start playing the little clubs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But that can take years, Jerry! Look at me. I'm already 31 years old! People my age are way ahead of me. I've got some catching up to do and I need your help. What do you say, Jerry? All I'm asking you to do is listen to my act. That's all. Is that asking too much?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I get calls from agents every day. All they want ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I tried getting an agent.   I did, Jerry. But you know how it is. You can't get an agent unless you're working and you can't get work unless you've got an agent ... or unless you know somebody. And the only person I know is you, Jerry. There is a long pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, why don't you call my office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could I?!? Oh, I knew you'd say that, Jerry. You don't know how many times I've had this conversation in my head. And this is the way it always turns out. That's why I had to sort of invite myself into the car tonight. I know it's kind of presumptuous and I really appreciate the time you've given me. But breaks like this don't just happen. You have to make your own breaks. The limousine starts slowing down as it pulls up before U.N. Plaza. It stops. LANGFORD gets out. PUPKIN follows. 3   EXT:   U.N. PLAZA APARTMENTS - NIGHT LANGFORD turn to PUPKIN,    looking to get rid of him as cleanly and gracefully as    possible. LANGFORD extends his hand. PUPKIN goes to     shake it but his hand is wrapped in the handkerchief. He     extends his left hand. LANGFORD shakes it awkwardly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice meeting you, Rupert.   I hope it all works out for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, Jerry. I don't know how to repay you. I'm a little short on cash this evening, but, if you don't mind some good, hearty food, I'd be honored to take you to dinner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, but some people are waiting for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I understand. Well, then, maybe I could repay you with a joke. LANGFORD is starting to walk into the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait a minute. How's this? The      first night you do your show from the coast,    you open this way. "Good evening, ladies    and gentlemen, it's great to be back    here in Southern California where you can wake up in the morning and listen to the birds coughing ... " LANGFORD (nodding but unsmiling) Not bad. Maybe. PUPKIN calls after LANGFORD who heads for the entrance to his building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Consider it a gift. Hey, Jerry! How about lunch? My treat!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (turning back before he enters the building) Call my office. PUPKIN waves with his bandaged hand, notices LANGFORD's handkerchief and unwraps it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the handkerchief) Thanks, Jerry. The CAMERA MOVES IN for a CLOSE-UP of PUPKIN in a kind of daze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, Mr. Langford. (To PUPKIN, angrily) How did you get in?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's alright, Vincent.   Mr. Pupkin's a friend of mine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (puzzled) Oh, I see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's alright. Now if you'd be good enough to find us a nice table. PUPKIN pushes a five dollar bill into VINCENT's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Certainly.   This way, please. VINCENT leads PUPKIN and LANGFORD to the "bullpen," a select spot in a corner of the restaurant.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : 4   INT:   SARDI'S RESTAURANT - DAY PUPKIN and LANGFORD stand at the edge of the foyer, waiting for the Maitre d' to seat them. VINCENT, the owner, spots them and hurries over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Here you are. Enjoy your lunch, gentlemen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is Eddie here today, Vincent?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll send him over. A WAITER arrives and hands them the menu.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our specialty today is Rizzofino Dolce Acqua a la Marinara con Spezi. Very good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sounds like a new opera.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Fine.   What comes with it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me. The three laugh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine.   For two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very good. The WAITER leaves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: You look tired, Jerry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It shows, does it? It's all these problems with the show. That and the custody suit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was sorry to read about that, Jerry. Charlene never should have gotten the kids. If there's anything I can do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I appreciate it, Rube. Just talking about it a little with you helps. Eddie arrives. He     is a small, slightly-bald man with greying hair and a    goatee. He wears a foulard under an open-necked shirt.     He carries a long sketch pad. He immediately sets up    a small easel and starts sketching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hasn't Eddie already done you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never mind. You were saying ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I've been giving a lot of thought to your situation, Jerry, ever since I saw you starting to lose ground in the ratings. And I think I know what the problem is. Too many of the same faces.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sure, people are getting tired of these people who live off game shows and talk shows and can't really do anything. They've seen 'em and heard 'em till they can't stand it anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, maybe you're right, Rube.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure I am. When a show runs out of surprises, it loses its audience. A YOUNG GIRL stands before PUPKIN and LANGFORD.   She hands PUPKIN her autograph book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's your name, dear?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dolores.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (writing) To Dolores, who sensed greatness. Rupert Pupkin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (reading it) Thanks, Mr. Pupkin. The GIRL leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see what I mean? What you need on the show is some unknown quantity, some brilliant talent making his television debut. Imagine the suspense. Who is this young guy? How will he do with the eyes of all America on him? Something like that has got to help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that's where you come in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not? Believe me,     Jerry, I'd give you the credit you deserve    and I'll stick with you. Anytime you need     me, I'll be there, doing a few minutes at    Guild scale.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd be grateful, Rube.     I really would.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All finished, Mr. Langford. EDDIE turns the caricature so PUPKIN and LANGFORD can see it. It's a picture of the two of them, facing each other and smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Jerry, you sneaky ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks good, Eddie. The WAITER arrives with a bottle of champagne.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Compliments of Mr. Sardi. EDDIE hangs the picture of LANGFORD and PUPKIN on the wall behind them among the hundreds of other caricatures -- from Bankhead to Sid Caesar to Bette Davis. The CAMERA PANS over these. We hear the champagne pop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How does your afternoon look?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What have you got in mind?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, we've still got time to catch the Cubs and the Mets out at Shea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not? But first, a toast. To you, Rube and your success.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, Jerry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, Jerry. PUPKIN takes LANGFORD's handkerchief and folds it reverentially, tucking it carefully into his breast pocket. He claps his hands together a few times for joy and dashes into the street to hail a cab.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the fish) Say hello to Jerry. On a shelf above the aquarium stand three pictures, one of two boys, roughly eight and eleven, flanked by a shot of each boy alone. LANGFORD walks to the end of the table where a covered dish and a New York Post await him. He lifts the covered dish which reveals a large, cold salmon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the fish) Say hello to Jerry. LANGFORD begins poking at the fish with his fork.    The phone rings. He answers it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Marsha, Jerry. Did you get my note? I left it on the back seat. Did you get it? I dropped it there before they pulled me out. Those guys hurt me, Jerry. (pause) Jerry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (icily) Who gave you this number?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be    angry with me, Jerry. I didn't know what    else to do; I've been trying you every    five minutes, I miss you, baby ...    Jerry? LANGFORD hangs up the phone and then takes it off the receiver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say goodbye to Jerry. He shakes his head wearily, returns to his dinner and turns to the inside pages of the New York Post.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss! RITA comes over.    PUPKIN smiles knowingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beer please, Miss.    Something imported.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heineken's alright?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. RITA serves him a Heineken's.     She stares at him, searching his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How have you been, Rita? She stares again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : 5   EXT:   U.N. PLAZA - NIGHT PUPKIN
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 6   INT:   LANGFORD'S APARTMENT LANGFORD enters his apartment. It is tasteful, modern, spacious and empty. A floodlight shines on a single setting at the end of a long dinner table. He walks over to a large aquarium and sprinkles some food for the fish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 7    EXT:   LEXINGTON AVENUE IN THE SIXTIES - NIGHT A cab pulls up in front of an all-night florist shop. PUPKIN dashes out of the cab and into the florist's. The cab waits.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 8    EXT:   LEXINGTON AVENUE IN THE SIXTIES - NIGHT PUPKIN dashes out of the florist's clutching a single red rose. He hops back into the cab which starts moving.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 9    EXT:   A STREET OFF BROADWAY - NIGHT The cab pulls up in front of Gil's Steaks and Chops, a restaurant of little distinction that has a few checkered tableclothed tables in the rear and a long bar at the front. PUPKIN stares through the window of the bar at RITA, the bargirl, an attractive, somewhat shopworn blonde in her late twenties. PUPKIN enters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 10   INT:   BAR-RESTAURANT PUPKIN goes to the near end of the sparsely-populated bar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: You're not Rupert Pupkin! PUPKIN smiles broadly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How the hell did you find me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sally Gardner, I met her after a matinee. Aren't you glad to see me?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, sure.    How is old Sally?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The same, I guess. You know, two kids, a nice husband, living in Clifton.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It figures.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A lot of the kids in our class have moved back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just thought I'd say hello. Here, I brought you a little something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (recognizing his style) Oh, yeah, Mr. Romance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't forget to put in an aspirin. It lasts longer. RITA fills a glass of water and puts in the rose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing's gonna keep it alive in this place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How have you been, dear, sweet Rita?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't have an aspirin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe a Rolaids would work. PUPKIN pulls out a pack of Rolaids and hands one to RITA who smiles vaguely and drops it into the glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, what are you up to these days, Rupert?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't you know you'd see me again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You still going to the movies?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're looking as beautiful as ever.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yeah.   I was a real knockout.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: I thought so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, here I am.     Local cheerleader makes good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I voted for you for Most Beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't have the nerve to tell you then, but I guess it's alright now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, nothing terrible's gonna happen, if that's what you mean. There is an awkward pause.    PUPKIN stares admiringly at RITA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, how are things with you, Rupert?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Great!   Everything's starting to break.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Is that right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. As a matter of fact, that's why I'm here. I've known about this place for a long time. I just didn't want to make my move until I had something to offer you. Everything's a question of timing. RITA stares at PUPKIN as he rattles on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter? RITA shakes her head in disbelief and chuckles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Christ, Rupert Pupkin!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) The two of us are often confused.     He's the one with the famous father. PUPKIN waits for a laugh. RITA just keeps shaking her head. PUPKIN looks around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (critically) You like this place? RITA shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, you got something better?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing tonight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tonight? RITA starts laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling reluctantly) What's so funny?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (still laughing) You call me up all junior and    senior year. Night after night after night,    right? And every time I'm wondering 'when    is this guy going to stop talking and ask    me out?' Well, now I know the answer.     August twelfth, nineteen seventy-six.     It only took you ten, eleven years to    work up to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I had asked you out?   Would you have gone?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not? RITA starts laughing again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Because I thought you were a jerk!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see! I was right! But that guy isn't me anymore. I look at my picture in the yearbook and I don't even recognize myself. I'm not the same guy, Rita. A bull-necked MAN in his early forties enters. He waves a brief hello to RITA as he walks by. RITA smiles and the MAN takes a seat at the far end of the bar.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Rita!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (to PUPKIN) Excuse me a minute, honey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not honey! I'm Rupert. RITA goes to the far end of the bar and serves the MAN a beer. They chat briefly as PUPKIN watches uneasily. Finally PUPKIN downs his beer and raises his glass.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Miss!     Miss! The MAN gets RITA's attention for PUPKIN.   RITA returns to PUPKIN and serves him another beer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: I'm in the mood to celebrate tonight. Why don't we go to this nice restaurant I know, talk over and times, get to know each other all over again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Well, tomorrow night I thought we'd go out again, talk some more, get to know each other even better.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How much?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: How much what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much do we have to get to know each other?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (emphatically) How much do we have to get to know each other before we start talking about that job?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not talking about any job.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then what's this big offer you were talking about?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You'll see.    Right now I'm asking you for a date.    How about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, Rupert.     But I'm busy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Busy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.   Busy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: But this is the biggest night of my life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've already got a date. The MAN at the end of the bar raises his glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that your date?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: None of your business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want to go out with him for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a good friend of mine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell him you're busy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's so important about tonight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything!    You don't understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I don't. It's been really nice seeing you, Rupert. Thanks for dropping in. But I've got some work to do. RITA leaves PUPKIN and returns to the far end of the bar where she once again resumes talking with the MAN. PUPKIN sits for a moment, gets up slowly and heads for the john. 11   INT:   THE JOHN - NIGHT He enters the john and goes to the farthest of the three urinals. A moment later, the MAN enters. He goes to the nearest of the three urinals. The two men stare at the wall before them but the obvious tension between them renders them both incapable of relieving themselves. PUPKIN glances over at the MAN's face, then immediately turns back to the wall as the MAN turns to look at him. The MAN glances quickly at PUPKIN and then returns to staring at the wall. PUPKIN sneaks a furtive glance at the MAN's penis. The MAN sneaks a furtive glance at PUPKIN's penis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss! RITA walks over reluctantly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Rita! RITA goes to the far end of the bar. She pours him another beer and settles against the bar, resuming her chat with him. PUPKIN looks for a moment and downs his beer. He raises his glass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss!   Miss! RITA returns to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 12   INT:   THE BAR - NIGHT PUPKIN emerges from the john, followed a moment later by the MAN. They resume their seats at each end of the bar. A third MAN has come in and is seated midway between PUPKIN and the MAN.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Listen to me for a second.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have work to do, Rupert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just listen. I'm at the start     of something really big. I don't     want to talk about it here but it's    going to happen soon and it's going    to be great -- for both of us.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No kidding?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: So see that guy some other night.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Rita! RITA turns to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: But I haven't finished! RITA returns to the MAN and pours him another beer. PUPKIN sits for a few moments, then downs his beer quickly. Again, he raises his glass.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Miss!   Miss! The MAN leans over the bar and tells RITA something. She opens a bottle of beer and hands it to the MAN who slides it down the bar towards PUPKIN. As the beer reaches the middle of the bar, the THIRD MAN seated midway between PUPKIN and the MAN raises his beer glass to take a sip just as the sliding beer bottle passes under his hand. The bottle stops right in front of PUPKIN who takes it and slides it back with equal force. At this moment, the THIRD MAN in the middle has finished his sip and has just placed the THIRD MAN's glass on the counter. The beer bottle collides with the THIRD MAN's glass, creating a mess. RITA glares at PUPKIN as does the THIRD MAN. PUPKIN shrugs an apology and RITA cleans up the mess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (to the THIRD MAN) I'll get you another one. As RITA cleans up the mess and pours a fresh beer, the MAN walks down the bar towards PUPKIN. He leans over him and puts a supposedly friendly paw on his shoulder. PUPKIN glances distastefully at the MAN's hand on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to PUPKIN) Look,    friend. I'm trying to have a nice    civilized conversation with the young    lady. Be a good little lad, huh,    and give us a break. PUPKIN looks up at the MAN who pats him on the back in a gesture of fraudulent friendship and menace. PUPKIN burps. With an effort, the MAN controls his temper and returns to his seat at the end of the bar. PUPKIN instantly raises his glass.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Miss!     Miss! The MAN advances towards PUPKIN with another bottle of beer. PUPKIN watches passively as the MAN pours half the bottle into PUPKIN's breast pocket and slams the half-empty bottle on the counter. The MAN walks down to the end of the counter where a smiling RITA is waiting. PUPKIN again gulps his beer down. RITA and the MAN stare at PUPKIN expecting him to raise his glass and call for another beer. PUPKIN just sits there. After a few moments, RITA and the MAN resume their conversation, but they keep glancing over at PUPKIN, expecting him to interrupt them with a call for beer at any moment. PUPKIN continues to sit there. Just as RITA and the MAN have settled back into their conversation, PUPKIN falls like a stone from the barstool onto the floor. He lies motionless. RITA and the MAN look at PUPKIN for a moment while the handful of other patrons glance at him and return to their drinks. RITA leaves the bar and goes to the rear of the restaurant, disappearing into the kitchen. As she does, the MAN walks over to where PUPKIN is lying inert and prods him cruelly with his foot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: C'mon, schmuck, wake up so I can kick your ass outta here. The MAN turns to the kitchen to see if RITA is returning. As he does, PUPKIN carefully opens one eye, grabs a free chair from a nearby cocktail table, rises and bangs the MAN smartly over the head. The MAN falls, out cold. PUPKIN straightens up quickly as the other patrons look on with interest. PUPKIN brushes off his suit, which is blue, just like the MAN's, and stands above the MAN just as the MAN stood above him, his back to kitchen. RITA emerges from the kitchen with the owner, MR. NICHOLS and a large black COOK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to NICHOLS) He was making trouble one minute and the next he was on the floor. RITA automatically reaches out as she talks for what she thinks is the MAN's arm. Instead, PUPKIN turns around smiling, leaving her too startled to speak. NICHOLS and the COOK lift the MAN to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, buddy, here we go. NICHOLS and the COOK lead the MAN, who is still groggy, out of the bar as RITA continues to stare at PUPKIN with a mixture of curiosity and amusement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, Tarzan. Where do we eat tonight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another one, Chan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to WAITER) Chopsticks, please. The WAITER nods and leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So all this time you've been thinking about me, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right, Rita.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kinds of things were you thinking? PUPKIN drops his eyes shyly.      RITA starts laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, ho! Those kinds of things!    Shame on you, Rupert.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: CHINESE RESTAURANT ON UPPER WEST SIDE

dialogue.raw_text: : 13   INT:   CHINESE RESTAURANT ON UPPER WEST SIDE - NIGHT We are in the kitchen watching two dishes being chopped, shredded and boiled in deep fat. The activity is frantic. WE FOLLOW the two dishes as a WAITER carries them from the kitchen to a booth where PUPKIN and RITA are talking. It is a painfully plain restaurant, shaped in a rectangle, with booths lining either side and a row of little tables in between. At the back is the kitchen and two phone booths, facing each other. An old Chinese WOMAN mans the cash register by the door. The WAITER sets the dishes down before RITA and PUPKIN and clears an enormous plate of spare rib bones from RITA's place. RITA hands the WAITER her empty cocktail glass. RITA and PUPKIN are facing one another.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rita, I assure you there was ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rupert Pupkin is an unclean person!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Rita. People will hear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in a whisper) Rupert Pupkin is an unclean person. Oh, come on, Rupert. Relax. Have a little fun. WAITER arrives with RITA's drink and chopsticks and a beer for PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a very important evening to me, Rita.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you know your nose wiggled when you talked?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It does?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Just the tip. Like a rabbit. (pause) Hey, are we gonna eat or what? I'm starving. PUPKIN serves RITA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It always looks like they put worms in this stuff.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Just taste. RITA tastes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Well, I guess it won't kill me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is supposed to be the finest Cantonese cuisine in the city.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah? Then what happened to the tablecloths? PUPKIN drops his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, don't worry about it.   This is fine. (She takes a long drink) I'm having a good time. So you've been devoted to me, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I used to see you at the Garden every year.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, the Follies. That was the right name for 'em. How did you know which one was me? We all looked like chickens. What I mean is, we all looked like the same chicken. I thought it was gonna be Rita Keane in the Ice Follies and I wind up looking like Henny Penny. RITA chuckles to herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You just didn't get the breaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Breaks, bullshit! My parents didn't have the money for the right coach. But what difference does it make? She starts laughing to herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I remember once we were down in Atlanta and the ice machine broke down. We did three hours of slush. Everyone was falling on their faces and hopping up with their arms open for a bow like the whole thing was planned. And the people ate it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I liked the show.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah? The Follies? You really must have been carrying the torch. What did you think when I got married? You knew I got married?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew it wouldn't last.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think I should have married you, instead, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peter Drysdale !     Really, Rita!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If he'd only been hit by a train. He was worth a helluva lot more dead than alive, I can tell you that. RITA raises her glass to the WAITER who is standing nearby, talking with another WAITER. As she does, a nice-looking young MAN sitting in the middle aisle raises his glass of beer to her and drinks it, as a kind of toast. RITA smiles briefly and her eyes return to PUPKIN. The YOUNG MAN is seated behind PUPKIN, facing RITA. The WAITER comes over and collects the glass. Throughout the rest of the scene, a subtle flirtation continues between RITA and the YOUNG MAN.

direction.raw_text: Are you seeing anyone? RITA starts for a moment, thinking PUPKIN has caught her looking at the YOUNG MAN.

direction.raw_text: Anyone special?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (chuckling) You mean am I "going steady"?   Rupert, I'm thirty-one years old!

direction.raw_text: What about that guy tonight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What am I supposed to do, huh? Sit home watching TV? He's just some guy. He's got his own aluminum siding business. He comes into the city sometimes, that's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't go out with him for his money?!?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, horrors! Look, Rupert, what do you think they pay me in that dump? Ninety-five bucks. And you don't get the world's greatest tippers in there either. Somebody has to take care of me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what I want to talk to you about, Rita. The WAITER arrives with RITA's drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's your favorite movie star?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are, Rupert.     Especially your nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just tell me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this some kind of game? Are you going to tell me something about my character?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You'll see.    Give me his name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: I can't think of anybody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've got to have one, Rita. Everybody does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Okay. Let's see.       (pause) Marilyn Monroe. PUPKIN slowly pulls out a leather-bound book from his inside jacket pocket.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Rupert!    Are we going to exchange phone numbers!? PUPKIN expertly flips to a middle page in the book and, keeping the book open, his finger pointing under a name, he turns the book to RITA.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: That's her name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her name! She signed this herself, especially for me. RITA starts flipping through the book, curious about the other names. She isn't paying any attention to what PUPKIN is saying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She wasn't a great actress but she had a real gift for comedy. She died tragically, you know, alone, like so many of the world's most beautiful women. I'm going to see that doesn't happen to you, Rita.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's this one? PUPKIN checks the book.

direction.raw_text: Burt Reynolds.

dialogue.raw_text: Mel Brooks.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pointing to other names) And that's Woody Allen and there's Ernie Kovacs -- he's dead -- and that one's Lauren Bacall.

direction.raw_text: You don't really know any of these people?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take a look at this. PUPKIN flips to one of the back pages and shows a name to RITA.

direction.raw_text: (squinting) I can't make it out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Try.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: This is really weird handwriting! Exasperated, PUPKIN follows the name in question with his index finger.

direction.raw_text: Rooooper ....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (guessing) Redford!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's Robert Redford.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No!    It's ... it's Rupert Pupkin PUPKIN tears out the page and hands it to her shyly.   RITA just stares at it and back at PUPKIN.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Don't lose it. It's going to be worth something in a couple of weeks. RITA start laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what I've been trying to tell you. Things are really breaking for me. I'm ticketed for stardom. RITA laughs harder, despite efforts to be serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only a couple of hours ago, I was talking to Jerry Langford, the Jerry Langford. Stop it, Rita! RITA pulls herself together for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We were talking about my doing my act on his show.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (suppressing a smile) Your act?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Get    that guy you knew from Clifton out of    your head right now. You're looking at    Rupert Pupkin, Rita. Rupert Pupkin, the    new King of Comedy. RITA starts laughing hysterically, in spite of herself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (getting a grip on herself) I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not me, Rita? A guy can always get what he wants if he's willing to pay the price. All it takes is a little talent and sacrifice and the right break. If you've got a friend in the right place, that's all it takes. And that's exactly what I have going for me right now. After all, crazier things have happened. RITA listens silently for a moment, then begins to giggle. As PUPKIN resumes speaking, we CUT between RITA and the YOUNG MAN. Their flirtation picks up steam. The YOUNG MAN raises his eyebrows as if to ask, "Are you interested in me?" She smiles. All the while, PUPKIN rattles on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You just don't realize what a shot on the Langford Show can mean. That's coast to coast, national TV, a bigger audience than the greatest comedians used to play to in a lifetime. A shot like that means a free ticket on the comedy circuit -- Flip Wilson one week, Cosby the next, then Sonny and Cher or Carol Burnett. And you've always got those other talk shows to fall back on -- Carson, Griffin. And all that leads straight in one direction, Rita -- Hollywood! That's when we really start living . How does this sound to you -- a beach house in Malibu, right on the ocean. You'll get a beautiful tan, believe me. And we'd keep a suite at the Sherry. That's the only place to stay when you're big. We could get something on a top floor and look down on all our old friends in Clifton and just laugh. How does that sound to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It sounds wonderful, Rupert, and I really hope you get what you want. But it's getting late and I'm a working girl. You know what I mean? The telephone at the back of the restaurant starts ringing. A WAITER in the background moves slowly to answer it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You going to spend the rest of your life in that place? Is that what you really want, talking about nothing with nothings? I thought you wanted something a little better than that and that's what I'm offering. Every King needs a Queen, Rita. I want you to be mine. What do you say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You really want to help me out? You see this. (She points to her lower back molar) A hundred seventy-five bucks. If you could spare fifty, say, until next Monday, that would keep three people really happy -- me, my landlord and my dentist. During RITA's speech, the WAITER has been working his way from the phone booth towards the front of the restaurant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Telephone for you, Miss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking puzzled) Me? Nobody knows I'm here.   You didn't tell anybody, did you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (getting up) What the hell's going on? CAMERA FOLLOWS RITA, who walks to the back of the restaurant and picks up the dangling receiver in one of the two facing booths, the other of which is occupied. 14   INT:   THE PHONE BOOTH - NIGHT RITA Hello?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who do you think it is? I've been staring at you all evening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you? The YOUNG MAN taps forcefully with his index finger on the glass door of his booth. RITA, hearing the noise, turns around and finds herself staring at the YOUNG MAN. She smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with repressed gaiety) You know who that was -- the bar.       I have to go back to work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did they know you were here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gathering her things) I guess I must have told them.      They need someone right away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (accusingly) You don't even care, do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, no.   I do. Really!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not the bar, Rita.    Don't tell me it's the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be angry. It has nothing to do with you. I had a nice dinner, really. It was great seeing you again. PUPKIN stare at her icily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on.    Let's see a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't we finish the evening up at the bar together? End the evening where it began?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After what happened there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I could at least drop you off!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (hurriedly making up her face) That's okay. Really. I can manage. Why don't you just go to a movie or something? Don't let me spoil your evening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But that wouldn't be right. RITA gets up and stands before PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (firmly) Look, Rupert. It's been a lot of fun, really. I'll see you sometime, huh?

direction.raw_text: But Rita! RITA starts moving towards the door.

direction.raw_text: Come on, Rupert.      I'm in a hurry. RITA marches out with PUPKIN trailing behind. He throws the check and the ten dollar bill at the CASHIER. 16   EXT.   THE STREET - NIGHT CAMERA FOLLOWS PUPKIN as he streaks out the door and jumps into the adjacent doorway, immediately peering down the street. He spies the YOUNG MAN and RITA walking about three quarters of a block down and follows them, keeping out of sight. They turn occasionally to see if he's around, then stop turning. They go around the corner and disappear into a large apartment building. PUPKIN rushes after them,   positioning himself across from    the building. He searches   the windows for some clue as to    where they have gone.    Finally a set of lights go on on    the fourth floor and a   MAN's shadow is seen closing two    sets of blinds.

direction.raw_text: Welcome to the pleasure dome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't kid around, do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) I do alright. What's your libation?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your potion. Your drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bourbon and soda.   Make it light. The YOUNG MAN goes to his chic little bar and starts fixing RITA a strong bourbon and soda. He also fixes himself a strong scotch and water. As he works, they talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You from the South?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what Southern people drink. Lots of bourbon.

direction.raw_text: What do people from Jersey drink?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I make it a point to study things like that. It's important to know people's backgrounds, their tastes, their culture. It gives you a little head start. The YOUNG MAN turns from the bar and hands RITA her drink.

direction.raw_text: I'm Chet. Whom do I have the pleasure of serving?
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pleased to meat you, Mary. (He lifts his glass) To our evening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rita Keane.    I want to talk to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rita Keane?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right. Oh, never mind.      I must have the wrong apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no Rita here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.     I know. I'm sorry to bother you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must have the wrong apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. PUPKIN pushes 4B.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leisure is America's fastest growing industry. Did you know that? Think about it. Short work weeks, more vacation. People need something to do with all that time and that's where I come in. Leisure Villages, Inc. We buy land an hour or so outside your metropolitan centers. We set up the bungalows, dig some lakes, lay out a golf course, you know, fix the whole place up so it's usable. Then young, personable guys like me show the people around. It the guy seems tight, we point out the investment factor. If he's a swinger, well, the bungalows are very private. If he's a sports nut, we talk up skiing and fishing and tennis. The phonograph starts playing Burt Bachrach.
direction.name: direction
