dialogue.raw_text: : 45   INT:   PUPKIN'S ROOM - DAY PUPKIN enters. WE SEE that it is a small room, furnished by the hotel in the plainest way. Nicely-done home-made collages of show business figures decorate the drab green walls. The room is neat and clean. PUPKIN goes directly to a plain table which holds two tape recorders -- one a small cassette the other a large table tape recorder. He picks up the microphone of the larger one and speaks into it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Testing.   Testing.   Testing. In the following montage, we hear in the background the replay of his "testing, testing testing" and various other noises -- a bit of his voice taped, a burst of laughter, the squeal of a tape recorder sent fast-forward, a sudden burst of applause, a scrap of theme music. At the same time, the CAMERA PANS about the room.    We look at the collages which include all the obvious show business figures, with a heavy emphasis on comedians from Chaplin and Keaton to Sid Caesar and Woody Allen. The collages also include such varied figures as Jimmy Carter, Julia Childs, Tom Seaver, David Brinkley, Muhammad Ali, Clifford Irving, Walter Cronkite and Mark Spitz. There is a special Kennedy section -- John F. and Bobby framed in black, Jackie in mourning and a picture of Teddy. There is also a trio of assassins -- Sirhan, Oswald and James Earl Ray. There is also a talk show collage with a photo of Langford in the center like a sun surrounded by Snyder, Walters, Carson and Griffin. One bookshelf holds a veritable library of comedy -- joke books, biographies of comedians, treasuries of American humor. Another shelf holds scores of tapes in their own little boxes, each one neatly marked, i.e., "LANGFORD MONOLOGUES:    7/5/72 to 9/9/72." "MISC. MONOLOGUES 6/13/68 to 8/1/69."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : PUPKIN sitting before the tape recorder lost in thought. Finally, he starts the larger recorder and lifts the mike.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: First, Miss Long. Thanks very much for your help at the office and for passing this along to Jerry. I appreciate it more than you know. PUPKIN stops the tape recorder and thinks again for a few beats. He then starts the large recorder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, Jerry. Before I begin, I just want to thank you for listening to this material and for the opportunity that you've given me. You know, lots of people think that guys like you, you know, people who have made it, lose their feeling for struggling young talent such as myself. But now I know from experience that those people are just cynics, embittered by their own failure. I know, Jerry, that you're as human as the rest of us, if not more so. (pause) Oh well, I guess there's no point going on about it. You know how I feel. So let's get on with the show.   The best of Rupert Pupkin! I've sketched out this little introduction in order to save you a little time. So close your eyes and imagine it's exactly six o'clock. You're standing in the wings and we hear Rick Ross and the Orchestra strike up your theme song. PUPKIN pushes a button on the cassette and we hear the theme song of the Jerry Langford Show, followed by the voice of BERT CANTER, the announcer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now, direct from New York, it's the Jerry Langford Show! Tonight, with Jerry's special guest ... PUPKIN deftly shuts off the cassette and substitutes his own voice for that of CANTER's. The large tape recorder keeps rolling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... the comedy find of the year making his television debut, Rupert Pupkin, the King of Comedy! PUPKIN rapidly races the cassette tape forward, then pushes down the "play" button. We hear a burst of thundering applause. PUPKIN lets the applause run for a while and then shuts it off. The large recorder keeps rolling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now you come on, Jerry, and do your monologue. Then, when the time comes, this is how I see you introducing me. You'll say something like this. "Ladies and Gentlemen we're going to do something a little bit different tonight. It isn't often that you can call someone a sure thing in the entertainment business. After all, the verdict is always in your hands. But I think after you've met my next guest, that you'll agree with me that he's destined for greatness. So, now, will you please give your warmest welcome to the newest King of Comedy, Rupert Pupkin!!!" PUPKIN pushes the cassette and we hear another enormous burst of applause. PUPKIN lets it run, listening intently. He stands up and faces a wall of his room, still holding the microphone. WE SEE that the wall is covered by a huge blow-up of an audience laughing and applauding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will somebody tell that lovely lady that the applause sign is off. The audience laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's a possible introduction, Jerry. Now let's move on to my act.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (suddenly a bit shy) I didn't want to take any chances with this ... uh ... Miss Long, so I ... uh ... thought I'd just bring it here myself. He hands CATHY LONG the package as though it contained nitroglycerine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We talked about this this morning, did we, Mr. ... ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pupkin.   Rupert Pupkin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yes. It's been some day. (pause) Well, I certainly appreciate your bringing this over, Mr. Pupkin, and we'll listen to it as soon as possible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. Er ... you don't have any idea how soon that might be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you can try checking with us tomorrow. We might know something by then. Otherwise, it'll have to be Monday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if I just sort of waited around here today, just in case? I'll stay out of the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd just be wasting your time, Mr. Pupkin. We won't know anything until tomorrow at the earliest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I wouldn't consider it a waste of time at all.    I'd be glad to do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, why don't you try us tomorrow. Okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tomorrow? ... Right. I'll do that. Thanks a lot, Miss Long. And thank Jerry. CATHY LONG smiles at     PUPKIN and    goes, leaving PUPKIN staring at a picture     of LANGFORD    on the wall. WE FIX on LANGFORD a moment and     PULL BACK    to see LANGFORD in what PUPKIN would imagine     his office    to be. 48   INT:   AN OFFICE - DAY A large, corner office furnished in royal red, with high ceilings and a huge desk. Potted palms and hydrangeas rest on a marble floor. LANGFORD is moving about restlessly, clutching PUPKIN's tape in one hand and waving it about. PUPKIN is seated on a comfortable couch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dynamite!    This is dynamite!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shyly) You think so, Jerry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I've been at this for fifteen years, Rupert, and I haven't come up with anything like this -- not me, not any of my writers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling with obvious pleasure) Well, I'm glad you like it, Jerry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me something, Rube. (pause) How do you do it? I'm not asking to use the material myself. I just want to know how you (LANGFORD waves his arms in a gesture of frustration) how you do it .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I don't know if I can explain it, really.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on.    Try, Rube.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well,    it just sort of comes. I think about    my life, see, mainly about the worst    parts, all the awful things, and I just    try to see them in a funny light. That's    all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (eagerly) Is that what you do? The worst parts, and then you look at them in a funny light? Is that what you do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More or less. It's hard to describe how its happens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But that's just it, Rube. It doesn't happen for me. Why do you think the show is in so much trouble? By the time I've done my monologue, everyone has switched to Carson. Maybe if you did a little writing ... ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, Jerry, I'd do anything I could to help out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You would? Great. Why don't you come out to my place this weekend and we'll hash it out. I'm having a few of my friends but we should be able to get a little work in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you mind if I brought someone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) A girl, Rube?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A very special girl, Jerry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd love to meet her. 49   THE HIGH-RISE OFFICE BUILDING ON UPPER BROADWAY - DAY PUPKIN emerges, lost in thought. Suddenly he notices MARSHA waiting nearby. She doesn't see PUPKIN. He sneaks off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cab, Jerry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's alright, thanks. WE FOLLOW LANGFORD as he walks. Some people don't notice. Others stare but leave him alone, a few commenting to their companions and pointing at him. A CAB DRIVER pulls alongside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Jerry. My brother can sing and juggle at the same time. How about puttin' him on your show? LANGFORD keeps walking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about it, Jerry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, I'm off duty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're Jerry!! LANGFORD pulls his cap a little more tightly around his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know something.   (She giggles) I undress in front of you every night and Larry here doesn't mind at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't get anything started with her until you're off the air. Your show is ruining my sex life, Jerry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well then, you'll just have to put on a better show than I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jerry!     God damnit! Just as MARSHA turns around, PUPKIN, unaware of her, walks cheerfully into the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir?     (recognizing him)   Oh, hi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.   How are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not bad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I help you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to see Jerry, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are ... ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Pupkin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a minute. The RECEPTIONIST dials a number.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : 45   INT:   THE LANGFORD TELEVISION STUDIO - NIGHT WE SEE a real audience laughing and applauding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : PUPKIN strides triumphantly onto the stage, nodding to acknowledge the applause. He stops center stage as the television cameras maneuver about him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : A SHOT of the "APPLAUSE" sign flashing, then stopping. Still, the applause goes on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : PUPKIN    raises his hands to quiet the audience. After a few moments    the applause dies down, except for a pair of hands in the    center of the orchestra. PUPKIN peers out to see who is    still applauding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : RITA, in the middle of the audience, applauds enthusiastically.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : PUPKIN on stage.    PUPKIN gives RITA a special smile and nod.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 46   INT:   PUPKIN'S ROOM - DAY PUPKIN stands facing the "audience" still holding the mike.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: THE RECEPTION AREA OF THE LANGFORD SHOW

dialogue.raw_text: : 47   INT:   THE RECEPTION AREA OF THE LANGFORD SHOW - DAY PUPKIN is pacing. He is wearing another suit, this one a broad-lapelled-grey. He is freshly shaved, is hair neatly combed, his shoes carrying a bright shine. He clutches a small flat box, neatly wrapped with the words 'FOR JERRY LANGFORD" written clearly across the top in large print. CATHY LONG emerges from one of the back corridors into the reception area.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: THE HIGH-RISE OFFICE BUILDING ON UPPER BROADWAY

dialogue.raw_text: : 50   EXT:   U.N. PLAZA - DAY It is a bright morning. LANGFORD, attempting to camouflage himself by wearing a cap over his eyes and his trench coat collar turned up, his eyes hidden behind dark glasses, walks out of the building. A DOORMAN is standing by the door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 51   EXT.   A MANHATTAN STREET - DAY LANGFORD stands at the corner, next to a middle-aged COUPLE.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: BROADWAY, A FEW BLOCKS SOUTH OF LANGFORD'S OFFICES

dialogue.raw_text: : 52   EXT:   BROADWAY, A FEW BLOCKS SOUTH OF LANGFORD'S OFFICES - DAY WE WATCH LANGFORD continue to walk, feeling what it is to be a celebrity out in public. After a few beats, we
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 53   EXT:   BROADWAY - DAY WE SEE MARSHA trailing LANGFORD. LANGFORD notices her and starts walking quickly. MARSHA walks quickly. LANGFORD starts jogging. MARSHA starts jogging. Finally, LANGFORD breaks into a sprint. MARSHA runs after him. LANGFORD disappears into his office building. MARSHA arrives several seconds later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: RECEPTION AREA OF JERRY LANGFORD SHOW OFFICES

dialogue.raw_text: : 54   INT:   RECEPTION AREA OF JERRY LANGFORD SHOW OFFICES - DAY PUPKIN enters. The same middle-aged, plump RECEPTIONIST is seated behind the desk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mr. Pupkin is here ... That's right ... (to PUPKIN) She'll be with you in a minute.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: But I wanted to see Jerry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Langford's not in. Miss Long will take care of you.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Alright. PUPKIN paces for a few beats. He smiles at the RECEPTIONIST. A beat later, CATHY LONG comes out, carrying the tape in its box.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Pupkin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: How are you today?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine, Mr. Pupkin. Thank you for your tape. We listened to it with great interest. And, frankly, Mr. Pupkin, we saw a lot of good things in what you're doing. We feel you have good potential. Very good potential.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) Thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why I'll be honest with you, Mr. Pupkin ...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We just don't think you're ready yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (baffled) Not ready?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, we just don't feel right now that you're right for Jerry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (rapidly, half-listening) Right for Jerry. Sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some of the material ... some of the one-liners, for instance ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... were not very strong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't care for some of the jokes, is that it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That"s right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. Good. I can take care of that right way. Thanks. Just tell me the ones you think should go. That would be a big help. (to the RECEPTIONIST) This is great. (to CATHY LONG) Which ones?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it's not just that, Mr. Pupkin. You see, Jerry likes to panel his guests, you know, chat with them afterwards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure.   Sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And frankly, we just don't feel you've got very much to talk about right now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I've got my whole life to talk about!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which is interesting to you, I'm sure and to your wife ... and to a few friends. But we feel that you should keep developing your act. Test it in some live situations. There are a number of clubs in the city you can try. And after a reasonable period, get in touch with us again and we'll be glad to send someone down to check out your progress. PUPKIN stares at her for a few moments as the tension grows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I ask you a question, Miss Long?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Are you speaking for Jerry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's put it this way, Mr. Pupkin. Mr. Langford has complete faith in our judgment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry to have to say this, Miss Long, and I certainly don't want you to take it personally, but I have to tell you that I don't ... I don't have faith in your judgment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm sorry you feel that way, Mr. Pupkin. But I'm afraid there's nothing that can be done about that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No ... No ... I'm afraid I'll have to disagree with you again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with strained politeness) That's your privilege, Mr. Pupkin. Now, if you'll excuse me, please, I have some things to do. I'm sorry the news isn't better. CATHY LONG turns to go.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Long? CATHY LONG turns back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: When are you expecting Jerry in?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He won't be in until very late this afternoon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's fine. Thank you. CATHY LONG stares at PUPKIN for a moment, glances at the RECEPTIONIST and then goes. PUPKIN takes a seat in the reception area. He smiles once more at the RECEPTIONIST. The RECEPTIONIST drops her eyes. A few beats go by. CATHY LONG passes by the entranceway and glances at PUPKIN. PUPKIN continues sitting there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there anyone else you would like to see?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's alright. I'm happy just waiting. A few beats pass in silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, would you mind waiting outside, please, Mr. Pupkin? This is a reception area, not a waiting room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand. PUPKIN remains seated. A few more moments pass. Several OFFICE PERSONNEL pass by the entranceway and glance at PUPKIN. After a few more beats, a large, plainly-dressed MAN in his mid-fifties emerges from the back offices. He goes over to PUPKIN, who stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Pupkin? I'm Raymond Wirtz, in charge of security for the Langford organization. WIRTZ puts his arm on PUPKIN's shoulder and, as the following dialogue unfolds leads him out the door, down the corridor and into the elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now I think you understand that we have certain rules here that are essential to the smooth functioning of our operation.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.     Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: And that without these rules, we really wouldn't be able to function at our best. You follow my point? PUPKIN nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now one of these rules is that only authorized personnel and those having official business with our organization are permitted on our premises. And that's why I'm asking you, Mr. Pupkin, to cooperate with us. They have reached the elevator and WIRTZ has pushed the button.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want me to leave the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right. It's nothing personal, Mr. Pupkin. Just doing my job. The elevator arrives. WIRTZ signals with his head that PUPKIN should enter. PUPKIN gets in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have a pleasant day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, did you give it to him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (out of a daze) Huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you get my letter to him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not in there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, if you don't want to give it him, okay. I'll get somebody else. But don't try to con me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you I'd try and I will. I'm going to wait for him right here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me the envelope, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, but ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw him go in myself!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jerry!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But they said he wasn't in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just give me the envelope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When did he go in?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ten minutes ago! That's when.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I saw him my ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he hasn't come out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been standing right here.      Now how about it? PUPKIN turns and goes back into the building.       MARSHA yells after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm staying right here!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with authority) Tell Jerry Langford I'm here, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, sir. Mr. Langford's not in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I happen to know he is .      So would you please tell him I'm here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.   He's not in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're putting your job on the line, lady. The RECEPTIONIST starts making a call inside. PUPKIN glances at her and walks right in to the inner corridors. He starts peering into the open doors of the offices that line the corridor. The whole place is like a gigantic maze. OFFICE PERSONNEL pass by him, taking no notice of him. He continues wandering around desperately, completely lost. A few beat later, he spots WIRTZ leading a pair of SECURITY GUARDS. PUPKIN keeps peering into offices quickly as he flees. The GUARDS and WIRTZ finally catch up to PUPKIN at the steno pool and, after a brief chase around the pool, they catch PUPKIN and subdue him. They start dragging him out past the eyes of the OFFICE PERSONNEL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (calling as he is dragged) Jerry! Jerry! (to WIRTZ) You're going the have a hell of a lot of explaining to do! (calling) Jerry!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You had your warning, Mr. Krupkin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jerry!   Help me. Jerry!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (screaming) Jerry!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If we see your face again, Mr. Pupkin, we'll call the police.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Start looking for a new job! MARSHA comes straight up to PUPKIN who is brushing himself off. His eyes are glazed and distant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does he have it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (abstractedly) Don't worry. I'll get it to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?   When? There is a pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This weekend. He asked me to go out there, to his house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are we going to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (patiently) Look, I told you, I've got some work to discuss with him. That's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But what about me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're with me .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's fine, but while you two are talking, what am I going to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can chat with the other guests.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure they'll be thrilled hearing about the wonderful world of draft beer. (pause) Let's tell 'em I'm a model, okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If they ask what I do, let's just say I model. You don't mind pretending just a little, do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it make you feel better. There is a pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is    a gas! Too bad nobody'll believe    it. (pause) After you guys are done    working, what happens? Are we going    out someplace, or what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure Jerry has something arranged. There is another pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do    these people do for fun? Do they    party or do freaky things or just    get drunk or ... I mean, What do    they do ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess they just sit around and talk and enjoy each other's company, like anybody else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Talk?!? What can you talk about for three or four hours?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do    you mean? They've got plenty to talk    about. They do things.    All kinds of    interesting things happen to them    and then they talk about them. What do    you think Jerry's show is all about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, a cocktail party with no drinks. That's what all those shows are. At least they help you get to sleep. There is a pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (glumly) Boy, this is going to be some great weekend.   I thought we were gonna have some fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) Just take it easy, Rita.     Everything's going to be fine. WE MOVE IN for a CLOSE-UP of PUPKIN who is fading out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : 55   EXT:   STREET OUTSIDE THE LANGFORD BUILDING - DAY PUPKIN comes out and takes up a position outside the door, preparing to wait for LANGFORD. MARSHA sees him and comes over to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: RECEPTION AREA OF THE JERRY LANGFORD OFFICES PUPKIN

dialogue.raw_text: : 56   INT:   RECEPTION AREA OF THE JERRY LANGFORD OFFICES PUPKIN enters briskly and goes up to the RECEPTIONIST.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : A CLOSE-UP of PUPKIN as he is dragged out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 57   EXT:   LANGFORD BUILDING LOBBY AND EXIT - DAY WE WATCH the SECURITY GUARDS and WIRTZ pitch PUPKIN out into the street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 58   THE BAR-RESTAURANT WHERE RITA WORKS - DAY PUPKIN enters the bar-restaurant. Through the window WE SEE him talking to RITA. He is voluble, animated. She looks skeptical, with a wry smile on her face. Finally WE WATCH him extract an answer from her. She shrugs, smiles and says yes. He comes walking out the door, his hounded expression softened by a smile.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: THE FITTING AREA OF A MEN'S STORE

dialogue.raw_text: : 59   INT:   THE FITTING AREA OF A MEN'S STORE - DAY WE WATCH PUPKIN getting fitted in a new suit, attended by a SALESMAN and a TAILOR.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 60   INT:   LUGGAGE SHOP - DAY WE WATCH PUPKIN buy a suitcase.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 61   INT:   CARTIER'S JEWELERS - DAY WE WATCH PUPKIN perusing the beautiful diamond, sapphire, and emerald rings and we take a few moments to PAN OVER these beautiful jewels as he sees them. Finally, he picks out a splendid ring with a single, middle-sized sapphire and hands a surprised SALESLADY the money in cash.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 62   INT:   SUBURBAN TRAIN - DAY PUPKIN and RITA are seated side by side. Since it is Saturday morning, the train is sparsely populated. A CONDUCTOR has just finished taking PUPKIN's tickets. RITA is edgy. PUPKIN is strangely calm and a little remote. He is wearing his new suit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 63   EXT:   A NEO-CLASSICAL MANSION It is a large white house with colonial columns set in the middle of a palatial estate whose rolling lawns are punctuated with fine old trees. We circle around to the back where LANGFORD, a handful of his FRIENDS (which can be familiar television celebrities) and PUPKIN and RITA are just finishing a lavish lunch on the patio. A pair of SERVANTS are clearing the table and serving the coffee and desert as the scene unfolds. As we arrive, we hear a loud burst of laughter. PUPKIN is regaling the COMPANY with stories.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Oh, you have no idea how bad it's gotten in New York. Now the muggers are so efficient that, each time they jump you, they take your name and address and put you on a mailing list. (the COMPANY chuckles) And once you're on the list, you're in real trouble, like this friend of mine who was mugged thirty-two times on his way home from work. (a little laughter from the COMPANY) A SERVANT places the desert, a little, elegant tart, in front of PUPKIN and RITA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to SERVANT) Thanks. The SERVANT smiles. As PUPKIN continues his story, he glances occasionally at RITA who has begun to nibble at her tart. PUPKIN also glances conspiratorially at LANGFORD who smiles back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what my friend does is get himself a dog, one of those huge German Shepherds. One night, he's walking the dog in Central Park when he hears this voice behind him. (in a German accent) Okay, Harry, drop your vallet and keep your hantz over your head or I bite your little fanny off. The COMPANY breaks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to LANGFORD) Looks like you've found yourself a winner, Jerry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking at PUPKIN) He's the one who found himself a winner. RITA looks up, smiles and blushes. The rest of the COMPANY smiles benignly and grows attentive as RITA returns to eating her tart. Suddenly she bites down on something hard. She fishes it out of her mouth and looks at it. The COMPANY giggles. It is the ring PUPKIN purchased at Cartier's. The COMPANY applauds lightly and laughs. LANGFORD lifts his wine glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To Rita and Rupert -- a short engagement and a long, happy marriage. The COMPANY drinks with murmurs of "Hear! Hear!"   RITA and PUPKIN beam. RITA looks lovingly at PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (the PUPKIN) Have you set a date?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking pointedly at LANGFORD) Oh, yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope we're all invited.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone's invited.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are met here in these extraordinary circumstances to join this man and this woman in holy wedlock. But, before we begin, let me voice a personal word of thanks to you, Rupert and to you, Rita, for choosing me to perform this prestigious ceremony. Because we are on prime time, I am going to discard my customary remarks in favor of a few personal reflections.   When I was principal at Clifton High and these two were students, I had very little faith that Rupert here would amount to very much. But like his teachers and his fellow students, I underestimated this fine young man.   Some say that this misjudgment is directly tied to my recent dismissal as head of the Clifton School System. But let me take this opportunity to set the record straight. Knowing that Rupert and Rita here were most certainly destined for a great career and a lifetime of happiness, I voluntarily stepped down. I would only here add my own wishes to those of millions of viewers for their continued health, wealth and boundless success. The OFFICIAL looks quickly past RITA and PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll be back to marry them in a minute, right after this word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear the CONDUCTOR calling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greenwich.    Greenwich next stop. Greenwich. PUPKIN and RITA grab their small suitcases and quickly move down the aisle towards the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at that one. How'd you like to live in that?!?! Or that one! What do you figure these run? The taxi stops in front of a walled lot behind which is visible a handsome English stucco home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to DRIVER) What's this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's gorgeous! PUPKIN is genuinely puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to DRIVER) You sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, friend, I wouldn't want to tell you how many times I made this trip.   (pause)    That'll be three seventy-five. PUPKIN, still puzzled, hands him a five dollar bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (abstractedly) Keep it. The DRIVER gets out and puts PUPKIN and RITA's bags, which he had stacked on the front seat, onto the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks. If you need a ride back, just ask the guy for Wayne. That's me. The CAMERA PULLS BACK as PUPKIN opens the gate and he and RITA walk up the drive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must be Jonno. I'm Rupert Pupkin and this is Rita Keane. Mr. Langford's expecting us. Jonno nods politely but uncertainly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (uncertain) Mr. Langford asked you to come?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right. Would you mind taking those up? Jerry and I have some work that may oblige me to stay overnight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Mr. Langford's not here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Out playing golf, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (still puzzled and unsure) That's right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe he'll finally break a hundred.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe it's better if you came back ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (interrupting) That's alright. We don't mind waiting. PUPKIN walks from the foyer into the living-room, leaving JONNO staring after him holding the bags. RITA walks into the living room after PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (worried) The table's only set for one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's from breakfast.     Relax, will you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into the phone) Let me talk to Jerry Langford please ... I know he is ... It's important.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (as though he owned it) How do you like it?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : 64   INT:   THE LANGFORD TELEVISION STUDIO The theater is packed. World Series bunting hangs from the balcony and the front of the stage. We hear RICK ROSS and the ORCHESTRA strike up Mendelssohn's Wedding March.   Down one aisle walks RITA, accompanied by the MAN whom PUPKIN hit over the head at the bar. Down the other aisle marches PUPKIN, accompanied by LANGFORD. The AUDIENCE cheers wildly. The two COUPLES walk to the stage where a white- haired OFFICIAL awaits them. BERT CANTER stands at his side. PUPKIN and RITA disengage from their ESCORTS and stand before the OFFICIAL. The music stops and the AUDIENCE grows quiet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 65   INT:   THE TRAIN - DAY PUPKIN and RITA are seated as they were.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 66   INT:   A SUBURBAN TAXI - DAY RITA is peering out the window.     PUPKIN is still lost in thought.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 67   EXT:   LANGFORD'S HOUSE - DAY PUPKIN and RITA stand before the front door. PUPKIN rings, After a few beats, the door is opened by an Indonesian HOUSEBOY. PUPKIN walks in right past him, RITA following behind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 68   INT:   LANGFORD'S HOUSE - DAY PUPKIN hands the HOUSEBOY the two suitcases as he talks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 69   INT:   LANGFORD'S KITCHEN - DAY JONNO is on the phone.   A black lady COOK stands at his side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 70   INT:   LANGFORD'S LIVING ROOM - DAY It is a handsomely furnished room, done in old American antiques and other tasteful pieces. There is a grand piano heavy with pictures in one corner and wall-to-wall bookshelves that are mostly full and mixed with a balance of classics and modern popular reading. The whole room marks LANGFORD as a man of discernment. The shelves also house a fine stereo and a small, discreet bar. RITA and PUPKIN walk in like strangers in paradise, awed by the obvious elegance and expense the room reflects.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (admiringly) I could live here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling proudly) It's the only way to live. RITA stands in the center of the room, ill at ease, while PUPKIN strolls about comfortably, picking up an ashtray here, a cigarette case there, inspecting the artifacts for inscriptions, clues, hints about LANGFORD's character and life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How come he isn't here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard the guy.     He's out playing golf.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't you tell him when we'd get here? PUPKIN continues to move about the room, fielding RITA's suspicious inquiries effortlessly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We didn't have time to iron out the details. Now just relax. We're the first guests, that's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (interrupting) That Jonno character hadn't even heard of us!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a little irritated) It probably slipped Jerry's mind. He has better things to think about than what he tells his houseboy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's just not time way I expected it, that's all. There is a pause. PUPKIN continues his investigation.      He has moved to the grand piano in the rear of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do we do now? PUPKIN is looking    at a picture of an American Gothic couple standing in front    of a wood-frame house. As he comments on the pictures, the    CAMERA PANS over them. They form a kind of slide-show of    LANGFORD's life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These are Jerry's parents. His father runs the Post office in Wolverine -- that's in North Dakota. PUPKIN then fixes on a picture of an eleven-year-old boy standing next to a puppet stage with a puppet (obviously held by the boy) staring at its master.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This one was in Newsweek. He started giving these puppet shows when he was still in grade school. WE SEE a picture of a very young LANGFORD seated before a microphone with some celebrity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And this is from his quiz show in St. Louis. Can you believe it?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sure I can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: That was the name of the show. WE MOVE to a picture of LANGFORD smiling at JACK PAAR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And here's when he wrote for Jack Paar. He made a hundred and fifty a week and look at him now. Another picture of LANGFORD with a group of women sitting in a studio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And this is his morning show. A picture of LANGFORD standing in a park with his two boys, eleven and eight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And his kids. He's divorced. RITA, who has been only half-listening, has picked up a small, beautifully enameled cigarette box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at this. I love these kind of things. Look at the work.   I've got this thing about boxes. RITA puts it down reluctantly, picks it up, then puts it down again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Langford? ... I'm sorry to disturb you ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much longer are we gonna have to wait?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. Until he gets back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do we have to just sit here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He should be back pretty soon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doesn't he have any music or anything? Let's get a little life into this place. It's like a funeral parlor. She walks over to the stereo and opens the cupboard beneath it, revealing rows and rows of records.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is more like it. She pulls out a record.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Rita.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, yourself. She puts the record on. Frank Sinatra starts singing "They Can't Take That Away From Me." She takes a big sip of her drink, puts it down and comes over to PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about a little spin, handsome?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here? RITA snuggles into PUPKIN and starts dancing him around. He resists feebly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Rupert.      I came up here for a good time. PUPKIN gives in and starts      dancing with her in the    style of the 1950's, elbow out, arm      up, box step. After a     few moments, PUPKIN closes his      eyes. He has reached a     moment of perfect bliss, his dream      girl in is arms. They     dance silently as we hear Sinatra      singing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The way you wore your hat, The way we danced till three, The memory of all that -- Oh no, they can't take that away from me, No ... they can't take that away ... from ... me. The orchestra plays.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You never could dance, could you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How would you know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh I danced with you a couple of times -- at the Sigma U party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were there with Tommy Winston.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't ask me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the one time I did ask you and you went with him anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I couldn't go with you !
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be serious, Rupert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it's all ended happily and that's what counts. RITA grows jumpy under his gaze.      She looks around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wonder what the rest of this place looks like?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure it's all very nice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gaily) Well, there's only one way to find out. RITA scampers over to the stairs and pauses on the first step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You coming or not? RITA bounds up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rita! CAMERA FOLLOWS PUPKIN up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you? There is no answer. CAMERA FOLLOWS PUPKIN from room to room. They are all guest rooms, neat, pretty, clean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Rita. This isn't funny. Finally, PUPKIN opens the door to another room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shocked) What are you doing, Rita?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love it! All those millions of women out there dying to change places with me right now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on.   We shouldn't be here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Relax, will you. Let me have a little fun, for Christ's sake. RITA gets off the bed and runs into the john.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at this. It's nicer than my whole apartment. PUPKIN enters the large, beautifully done bathroom.   RITA examines her face in the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (urgently) Let's go, Rita.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boy, I really need some sun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rita, this is Jerry's ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lay off, will you, Rupert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But we have no right ... RITA picks up a can of shave cream and squirts a large dollop in PUPKIN's face. WE COME IN for a CLOSE UP of PUPKIN's face, buried under shaving cream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That wasn't funny, Rita. RITA hands him a towel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here. She looks around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now for something that smells nice. She swings open the cabinet with a flourish. The door swings open violently and the mirror shatters against something as pills and bottles tumble into the sink. PUPKIN and RITA stand there, staring at each other. RITA begins to laugh, but her laugh is cut short by the slam of the downstairs door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: JONNO and the COOK have moved out to greet him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking around) Where are they?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was going to call the police but then I thought to myself 'what if they are Mr. Langford's friends?' We hear some whispers and scuffling at the top of the stairs. LANGFORD, JONNO and the COOK look up. PUPKIN comes bounding down the stairs jauntily with RITA following cautiously behind. PUPKIN has large traces of shaving cream behind his ears and on his neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Jerry.   We were just freshening up. PUPKIN stops at the base of the stairs, turns around, and waves RITA down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to RITA) Come on, Rita. No need to be shy. PUPKIN smiles conspiratorially at LANGFORD.       RITA comes slowly down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jerry, I'd like you to meet Rita Keane. Rita, say hello to Jerry!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : 71   INT:   THE KITCHEN - DAY JONNO is holding the phone, waiting.     The COOK stands, looking at him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 72   INT:   THE LIVING ROOM - DAY RITA has just finished fixing herself a drink. She takes a large sip and starts pacing around. PUPKIN is seated.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pulling back)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 73   INT:   THE DINING ROOM - DAY JONNO stands a few feet from the kitchen door, staring at RITA and PUPKIN dancing in the living room, an unbelieving, anxious expression on his face.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 74   INT:   THE LIVING ROOM - DAY The music has stopped momentarily and PUPKIN and RITA disengage. PUPKIN looks lovingly at RITA.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 75   INT:   UPSTAIRS - DAY There is no sign of RITA.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 76   INT:   A BEDROOM - DAY It is clearly LANGFORD's bedroom with a few clothes strewn about, and other signs of being lived in. RITA lies on the bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 77   INT:   A LAVISH BATHROOM - DAY RITA
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 78   INT:   THE FOYER LANGFORD has entered, drawn and businesslike.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (tentatively) Pleased to meet you. LANGFORD nods imperceptibly, his face tense, his eyes alert. RITA, reading her frigid reception, looks to PUPKIN who walks blithely past LANGFORD into the living room, toward the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's your pleasure? PUPKIN glances at the small mess he has left on the bar and turns back to LANGFORD who has moved into the living room with JONNO and the COOK a few steps behind. PUPKIN flashes LANGFORD an apologetic smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to LANGFORD) We've already taken the liberty, so to speak. Rita was a little nervous. It isn't every day she meets someone like you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's going on here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've been sitting around, waiting. That's all. How was your golf game?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told them you weren't here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He did, Jerry. He was very helpful. We had to take an early train. There was nothing else until after one. (pause) I brought the material. It's upstairs, in my bags. (pause) Where is everybody?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other guests! (in a confidential tone) We're getting a little hungry, to tell you the truth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (as though confirming what PUPKIN said) You are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (backing off) But we don't mind waiting, do we, Rita? RITA says nothing. She has sensed something terribly wrong and is slowly backing away from PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, I could have you arrested, both of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (seizing the idea) You know you could! And there'd be absolutely no way we could prove we belonged here. I never thought of that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you should have before you ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (still fixed on the idea) Maybe we could work up a routine about that, about a guy who throws all his friends in jail. Let's talk about that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sharply) Let's not .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, Jerry. Whatever you ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (exasperated) Look, if you've got something for me to sign, let's have it and get it over with so I can get back ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (interrupting) That wouldn't be right, Jerry. Not in your own house!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (summoning his last bit of patience) I have a lot of work to get to. (to JONNO) How did they get here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We took a taxi, Jerry ... But don't worry about us. You go ahead and do your work and we'll just take a stroll around until lunch is ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a little thick, aren't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling as though complimented) Well, maybe a ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's he's saying, Rupert, is that he wants us out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't listen to her, Jerry. She doesn't understand anything about us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't get me into this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to JONNO) Call the station. JONNO goes back into the foyer, followed by the COOK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There'll be a cab here in a few minutes. Now if you'll just wait at the gate ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, Jerry, if I've said anything out of line, let's chalk it up to inexperience, okay? I'll just go upstairs and get my tape and we can start working. It shouldn't take long and then you'll have the rest of the afternoon to yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've told you just as clearly as I can. I want you out of here and I want you out now. Scram, beat it, vamoose, out! Is that plain enough! RITA deftly pockets the enamel box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But what about my material?    When are we going to go over it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Rupert, the man wants us to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell her she's wrong, Jerry!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, Mr. Langford. I didn't know anything about all this. I hardly know this guy. I haven't seen him in years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rita!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So if there's anything I can do, any way I can make this up to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's nothing, Jerry. She's just some girl who works in a bar. Don't let her spoil things. LANGFORD starts herding RITA and PUPKIN towards the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come on.   Let's go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: All I'm asking is fifteen minutes. That's all. Just long enough to listen to my act. Is that asking too much -- fifteen minutes of your day against my whole life?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll call the police if I have to. LANGFORD realizes he is being hard.    He stops for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have my own life, that's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But what about me , Jerry? What about my life? I made plans -- based on what you said. You can't just turn your back on me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not telling you again. There is a long pause as the truth finally sinks in. PUPKIN just stares at LANGFORD with disbelief that turns to anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So this is the way it   works when you're big, huh? You    just play with people. Is that part    of the kick, Jerry? (pause) I can     see I was all wrong about you. All    wrong. RITA starts tugging at PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Rupert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to RITA) Shut up! (to LANGFORD) You weren't my friend at all, were you? You were just playing some kind of game with me. Well, that's not going to stop me, Jerry. I'm just going to work a little bit harder, that's all, use a little bit more enterprise. And not count on anybody. That's where I made my mistake. I can see that now. PUPKIN picks up the pair of small suitcases.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (glaring at LANGFORD) Come on, Rita. We're wasting our time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (baffled and angry) What did you think was going to happen? You think he'd just ... ? What's the matter with you? (pause) You can't just walk into a guy's house! And what about me? What did you ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (interrupting in a calm but firm voice) Shut up, Rita. I'm thinking.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : 79   EXT.   LANGFORD'S FRONT DOOR - DAY PUPKIN strides out with RITA following.     She casts LANGFORD an apologetic glance as she goes. The     door slams behind them. They walk down the path silently     for a few moments as the CAMERA PULLS UP, following them    in an OVERHEAD SHOT. We hear them start talking as they make    their way towards the gate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 80   EXT:   OUTSIDE THE U.N. PLAZA - DAY CUT TO: 81   INT:   A NEW MERCEDES BENZ - DAY MARSHA sits at the wheel of this lavishly appointed sedan, her face made up as though she were going to a fancy party. PUPKIN sits on the other side of the front seat. His ex- pression has changed somewhat from the PUPKIN we have seen. He is less wide-eyed, less innocent, tougher.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (whining) How much longer?!?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want him or not? There is a pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sure he's in there?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Certain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (with obvious delight) My parents are going to be furious ! PUPKIN pulls a toy revolver from his jacket pocket and looks it over. MARSHA glances at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It looks real.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the whole point. (gesturing with his head towards the entrance of the building which is some 50 yards away) Pay attention. MARSHA looks towards the entrance.   A few beats pass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if he doesn't come down?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: But what if he doesn't?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll come back tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And wait again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, you're going to have him all to yourself. What else do you want? A MAN resembling LANGFORD walks out the entrance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that him?!?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure I'm sure. That looks too much like him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When it's him it doesn't look like him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep watching. PUPKIN closes his eyes and rests for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What should I do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait a second and follow him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Mercedes prowls a quarter of a block behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too busy.   Keep going.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The street is practically empty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go past him and stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just keep walking or I'll kill you right here. LANGFORD looks at PUPKIN in terror.        He falters a bit, out of fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said keep walking. This is a gun in my pocket and I've got nothing to lose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (who keeps walking) What do you want?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just keep walking and don't talk to anybody. I'll tell you what to do. A MAN    coming the other way stops and stares at LANGFORD out of    curiosity. PUPKIN and LANGFORD keep walking. They get to    where the Mercedes is waiting. PUPKIN jabs LANGFORD in the    ribs with the gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get in!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, this is ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (interrupting) Just shut up and get in. LANGFORD gets in the front seat.     PUPKIN follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Jerry. LANGFORD looks over and recognizes MARSHA.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's him. PUPKIN's eyes snap open. WE SEE LANGFORD, concealed in his trench coat, dark glasses and tightly pulled cap start walking east.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 82   EXT:   A STREET GOING EAST - DAY LANGFORD is walking innocently towards his offices.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 83   INT:   THE MERCEDES - DAY MARSHA
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 84   EXT:   ANOTHER EASTBOUND STREET - DAY LANGFORD continues walking.

dialogue.raw_text: : 85   INT:     MERCEDES - DAY PUPKIN
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 86   EXT:     THE SAME EASTBOUND STREET - DAY WE STAY with LANGFORD as he walks.  WE SEE the Mercedes pull past him. Suddenly PUPKIN is IN THE FRAME, walking side by side with LANGFORD.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 87   INT:     THE MERCEDES - DAY LANGFORD moves to the middle of the front seat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: UP records his reaction of sheer terror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't like being so rough out there, Jerry. But I wanted you to know that I meant business. I didn't want anything happening to you over some misunderstanding. LANGFORD just stares at him, frozen with fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now I know you're wondering    what this is all about. Actually     you've got nothing to worry about.     You just do what I tell you and    by, say, midnight, you'll be safe and    out of here. Of course if you try     anything clever, I'll kill you -- or    Marsha will. She knows how to use     this too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You realize what you're saying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Jerry. This isn't a spur of the moment thing.    Give me a little credit, will you. PUPKIN looks over to a small phone table with a chair next to it. He motions to it with his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to LANGFORD) Sit down. LANGFORD docilely sits by the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, you're going to call your office and tell them this: that unless a man who identifies himself as the King is allowed on the show tonight as the first guest, they'll never see you alive again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll say it again ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bert Thomas! ... He's in a meeting, Mr. Langford ... I see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He says it's urgent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) Yeah? Well, tell him I'll call him back. (to the others) It's that Martino kid, the impressionist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then try again!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah? ... Okay, Martino, let's stop the bullshit ... what? ... Okay, I'm listening. WE WATCH THOMAS' expression as it turns from skepticism to concern bordering on alarm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me that again? ... Wait a minute. What do we call our second cameraman?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into the phone) Helen Keller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (warning) No tricks, Jerry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't do anything, Jerry.     Stay right there. Tell him we'll do     anything he wants. Tell him to cool     it. Are you okay? ... Look, tell him    to call us about five, okay. We'll     let him know what to do. And don't do     anything stupid. THOMAS puts down the phone.

direction.raw_text: (calls to his SECRETARY) Vivien! THOMAS' SECRETARY appears at the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get me the number of the F.B.I. right away. And get me Crockett's office. And keep your mouth shut about this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to PUPKIN) What do you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to LANGFORD) I had to guess on the sleeves. (to PUPKIN) He gets to keep it, doesn't he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, if he isn't dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (panicky) I know he's in a meeting and I don't care. I've got to talk to him! ... No, he can not call me back. Don't you understand? This is an emergency ... NONE OF YOUR BUSINESS!

dialogue.raw_text: : 88   EXT:   A BROWNSTONE-LINED STREET IN THE EAST EIGHTIES - DAY WE SEE LANGFORD get out of the Mercedes which is parked in front of a fire hydrant. LANGFORD follows MARSHA into a brownstone. PUPKIN walks behind LANGFORD.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 89   INT:   MARSHA'S APARTMENT - DAY PUPKIN, LANGFORD and MARSHA enter. It is an absolutely stunning studio apartment, furnished lavishly by Marsha's parents for their daughter in antique furniture suitable for a woman of fifty. MARSHA has imprinted her own stamp on the apartment in two ways: First, the place is abso- lutely chaotic. Secondly, there are a number of blow-up pictures on the wall. A picture of LANGFORD sits on the bureau. There is a big brass bed with an ornate brass frame at the foot. LANGFORD stares at MARSHA and PUPKIN. PUPKIN closes the blinds and turns on the lights. MARSHA trains the gun on LANGFORD. PUPKIN finishes his work and takes the gun back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 90   INT:   BERT THOMAS' OFFICE     - DAY It is a large office in two pieces. A SECRETARY sits in the smaller part next to the door of the larger section. Her phone is ringing. She answers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 91   INT:   A CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY THOMAS, a young, trim executive in his late thirties, in modish dress, sits at the table with several other PEOPLE, including CATHY LONG. They are sipping coffee from con- tainers. There are memos and lists and other papers on the table. The SECRETARY stands at the doorway. THOMAS and the others are looking up at her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 92   INT:   MARSHA'S APARTMENT -- DAY LANGFORD sits by the phone with PUPKIN a few steps away, holding the gun and MARSHA looking on. LANGFORD looks desperate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 93   INT:   BERT THOMAS' OFFICE - DAY An irked BERT THOMAS wearily picks up the phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 94   INT:   MARSHA'S APARTMENT - DAY The scene is as before, only now LANGFORD is sweating a bit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 95   INT:   BERT THOMAS' OFFICE - DAY THOMAS is still at the phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 96   INT:   MARSHA'S APARTMENT - DAY LANGFORD is standing awkwardly in the middle of the room, wearing a sweater that matches the patch of cloth we saw in the envelope MARSHA gave PUPKIN. PUPKIN is still training his pistol on LANGFORD and MARSHA is appraising the fit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 97   INT:   THOMAS' OFFICE - DAY THOMAS is on the phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 98   INT:   MARSHA'S APARTMENT - DAY LANGFORD is seated on a chair whose back is pressed right up against the high, ornate brass bedstead at the foot of the bed. MARSHA trains the gun on LANGFORD now. PUPKIN is unpacking a suitcase. He takes out a handsome blue suit, ruffled shirt, a bow tie, black shoes, underwear, socks, shaving equipment, soap, a hairbrush, a clothesbrush, a small shoe shine kit, aftershave lotion, deodorant and a dozen or so rolls of inch-and-a-half wide adhesive tape. He removes this stuff from a suitcase that is barely big enough to hold it -- so the mere packing of all this para- phernalia into such a small space represents something of an achievement. As he takes the stuff out, he talks to LANGFORD, his back turned to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: This wasn't an easy decision for me, Jerry, believe me. For one thing, I knew it meant we could never be friends again and that hurt me. It's hard to lose a friend, even one who has let you down. You always hope you can patch things up. You know, a guy like me doesn't make friends that easily. PUPKIN pauses a moment, then turns to LANGFORD, his voice filled with emotion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why didn't you just listen to the tape when I asked you? Then I wouldn't have to be doing all this. Was it really too much to expect -- a few minutes of your time to listen to something I'd worked on my whole life? LANGFORD's eyes shift rapidly.   He is obviously calculating how to deal with PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with disarming charm) Hey, if that's what's bothering you, let's go over to my office and listen to that tape right now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you crazy, Jerry? Do you know what would happen to me? MARSHA listens to this exchange a bit nervously.   Gesturing to her gun, she says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I going to have to hold this thing all day? PUPKIN sees she has lowered it practically to her side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to MARSHA) Just keep it on him. (to LANGFORD) You know, Jerry. Friendship is a two- way street. All that time I was worrying about you and your ratings and everything, you couldn't have cared less about me. LANGFORD thinks rapidly for a beat or two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right. You know that? I was thoughtless. It's just that when you're doing a big show, it's hard to tell who your friends really are. I was wrong. I apologize. Why don't we just shake hands and forget the whole thing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (suspiciously) That's easy to say, Jerry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I mean it. I'll tell     them that the whole thing was a joke    and then we can go to my office and    listen to that tape. Come on. What      do you say? LANGFORD rises with his hand extended toward PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to LANGFORD, sharply) Sit down! LANGFORD looks to PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said sit ! LANGFORD reluctantly sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to MARSHA) What's the matter?     You heard what he said.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of a sudden, with a gun on him, he wants to make up and be friends. And, once he's out the door, what happens then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happens then, Jerry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You get to his office and they jump you, that's what happens, Rupert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's right, Jerry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not if I tell them not to. This is Jerry, Rupert, I give you my word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to MARSHA) He gives me his word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah? And what else? Come on, Rupert, I'm sick of waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what else, Jerry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Rupert. My word's good enough, isn't it. PUPKIN stares at LANGFORD for a few beats. Then he shakes his head sadly and says in a very quiet, discouraged voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Jerry. It's not. (to MARSHA) Keep the gun up ! PUPKIN comes over to LANGFORD with a few rolls of adhesive tape in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry to do it this way, Jerry, but I'm no good at knots. Just put your arms up and out, okay? LANGFORD spreads his arms back against the brass bedstead. As PUPKIN goes to tape them, LANGFORD tries to grab him, but, with sudden, demonic force, PUPKIN pins him against the bedstead. They are practically nose to nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, no, Jerry. None of that.      Now hold still.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PATTEN, and his assistant, GIARDELLO.   They are in the midst of debate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I tell you, the bureau is doing everything possible to locate Mr. Langford. Right now our men are out checking out every radical group in this city.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Radical?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're willing to sacrifice their leader in order to get their message across, aren't they? You've got to figure that this is a desperate outfit. I don't know who they are anymore than you do. But I do know I've got to stop them. Otherwise, what you're seeing here is just the first of a whole wave of these kinds of kidnappings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (upset) Does this mean we're not supposed to put him on?!?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who am I addressing, please?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's Bert Thomas. He produces the show.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm only saying, Mr. Thomas, that we can't allow this to reach the public. When the kidnappers call in, of course you're going to be cooperative. Promise them anything they want. After all, this King character is going to have to show up sooner or later. And once we get our hands on him, he'll tell us where Mr. Langford is. PATTEN grinds his fist into his palm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: WE SEE PUPKIN in the shower, shampooing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The scene is as before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. Let him go on if you have to. It's just a taping. You can always erase him afterwards, can't you? (pause) All I'm saying is this: don't put him on the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's fine, Inspector, but let's say he finishes his bit and you've worked him over ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is light laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, questioned him and he still won't talk. We get to eleven thirty and what do we do? Do we air him or what? There is a heavy pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would say no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But they might kill Jerry!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (breaking in) Okay, Burt. (to PATTEN) Thank you, Inspector. We appreciate your position and we'll do all we can to cooperate with you.   But I have to tell you right now that, if it comes down to it, we're not taking any chances with Mr. Langford's life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand but ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (interrupting) If your men haven't been able to locate Mr. Langford by air time, we're going to have to put this King guy on, no matter what he's said. After all, Inspector, what's ten or fifteen minutes of talk show time against a man's life?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: WE SEE PUPKIN in his new suit and ruffled shirt, impeccably groomed, standing next to the bed. He is talking to LANGFORD but we don't see anyone but PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Open. (pause) Bite ... Good. He is wrapping LANGFORD's mouth shut but all we see is that he is doing something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you breathe? Both ways?         In and out? WE    PULL    BACK TO SEE LANGFORD    nodding. He is strapped to the    bed    with tape and encased    like a mummy, only his eyes and    nose    showing. PUPKIN has     wrapped him in tape from tip to    toe.     MARSHA emerges from    the kitchen stirring something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've got until around midnight. Have a good time. (to LANGFORD) So long, Jerry! Wish me luck. PUPKIN leaves.

GIARDELLO           is at a second phone and starts placing a call. PATTEN           stands next to THOMAS. There are two other PLAINCLOTHESMEN          in the room, CROCKETT and CATHY LONG.

direction.raw_text: Late afternoon. MARSHA is setting the dining room table for two. She talks as she works.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got so much to tell you I just don't know what to begin with. Are you okay? LANGFORD mumbles incoherently through his gag and tape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. Tell me if you're not. I guess you're wondering why I do stuff like this. I think it's because I'm a Leo, but my shrink says I'm pathologically rebellious and self-destructive. You don't think I'm self-destructive, do you? LANGFORD, mummified, again mumbles and struggles a bit in his bonds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew you wouldn't. That's 'cause you're the only person in the world who really understands me.
