direction.raw_text: Can Randall* sub for Jerry? [*Tony Randall is one of any number of substitute hosts.]
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His agent's calling us back but it looks good. I only told him Jerry's sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if worse comes to worse, Canter can always carry it. (to CATHY LONG) Let me see your list. CATHY LONG hands CROCKETT a blue piece of paper.   He glances over it quickly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Any one of these a writer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pointing to a name on the list) McCabe. The Vanishing Siberian Tiger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if we don't run this King guy? Who'll fill the time?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll stretch the other guests. But I think we're going to wind up running him. For one thing, we've got to think about Jerry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And from a news point of view, we've got a responsibility to air this story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exactly, Lou. (pause) I mean, who would you rather watch -- some tiger expert or a live kidnapper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But nobody's going to know he's a kidnapper. They'll think we've gone crazy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then they'll read about it in the papers tomorrow and, believe me, tomorrow night, everyone in America will be watching Jerry talk about his experience. And he can put this King guy on rerun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're going to put him on twice?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if his stuff's unusable?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And remember what Patten said about ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold on. (pause) We can always edit the guy. And, as for a wave of these things, I just don't buy the idea that there are that many people out there crazy enough to spend their lives in prison for a few minutes on television.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PUPKIN walks purposefully down the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The street is quiet. Suddenly three cars pull up and some dozen PLAINCLOTHESMEN get out. Two wait outside the theater; the ten others disappear inside through the backstage entrance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PUPKIN is now walking cross-town, towards the theater.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A line of some 100 PEOPLE has gathered outside the theater. A sign at the bottom of the poster showing Langford reads "Tonight's Guest Host: Tony Randall."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From the POV of the stage, WE WATCH six PLAINCLOTHESMEN descend into the orchestra and take widely scattered aisle seats. When the last has taken his seat we ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Depending on the season, it is either dusk or late afternoon. The USHERS swing the doors open and the TICKETHOLDERS file in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PUPKIN is crossing Broadway, a few blocks from the theater.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the center of the stage, a pretty MODEL used solely to test color quality sits in Langford's chair as several MEMBERS of the Tactical Patrol Force admire her considerable cleavage. A number of TECHNICIANS go about their work. CAMERAMEN move to and from their stations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Four PLAINCLOTHESMEN are gathered behind the stage door. They watch ZSA ZSA GABOR (or some other sexy talk show celebrity) enter and then return to talking among themselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The situation appears normal. Only the regular backstage door GUARD, a big, grey-haired man, stands at the door. Nearby two other young MEN, in colorless suits, stand talking. We WATCH CLARENCE MCCABE, a writer, his plain WIFE and her PARENTS arrive in front of the theater, locate the backstage entrance and present themselves before the GUARD.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a bit pompously) Good evening, officer. This is the backstage door I take it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your name please?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clarence McCabe, the writer. And this is Mrs. McCabe and her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Solters of Cleveland.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (checking his list) I'm sorry, sir. I don't see you here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm on the show tonight, officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you're not here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (getting a bit agitated) Look, Cathy Long gave me instructions to present myself at a quarter to six. May I see her please?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm under strictest orders tonight to admit only authorized personnel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (huffy) This is absurd. (to the others) Wait right here. MCCABE marches past the GUARD and rushes to the backstage door. He opens it. The GUARD trails behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop him!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The four PLAINCLOTHESMEN jump MCCABE and start pulling him downstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PUPKIN arrives at the backstage door.      Seeing no one, he walks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MCCABE has just been hustled before PATTEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you the King? MCCABE looks baffled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PUPKIN is looking for a familiar face.     He approaches a CAMERAMAN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (getting CAMERAMAN's attention) Excuse me. The CAMERAMAN looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm the King.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PATTEN is sitting behind a desk. MCCABE is standing before him, still securely held by four PLAINCLOTHESMEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't talk to me about tigers!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PUPKIN approaches the STAGE MANAGER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to STAGE MANAGER) I'm the King.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) What can I do for you, your highness? CATHY LONG passes by.     She spots PUPKIN, and walks swiftly over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The lights are dimmed. Music is playing on the phonograph. Two candles burn on the elegantly-set dinner table. MARSHA stands in the middle of the room, in front of LANGFORD. She is singing. LANGFORD is still encased in tape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (singing to the music) "I'm gonna love you, Like no one's ever loved you, Come rain or come shine, Happy together, unhappy together, And won't it be fine."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now PUPKIN stands before PATTEN, held by PLAINCLOTHESMEN who frisk him and hand PATTEN the autograph book. GIARDELLO stands next to PATTEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the PLAINCLOTHESMEN) I hope you brought me the right guy this time. (to PUPKIN) Where's Jerry Langford?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to GIARDELLO) Are you on the show?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Mr. King. That's my assistant, Mr. Giardello.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to see someone on the show.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you tell us where Mr. Langford is and we'll let you see anyone you want.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just get me someone from the show. PATTEN starts browsing through the autograph book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Mr. King. Let's not fool around. (looking up from the book) Should we know about any of these people?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing to the book) That's Orson Bean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see.   (to GIARDELLO)   Check these out. GIARDELLO starts looking through the autograph book.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : 123   INT:   BACKSTAGE - EVENING.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing here, Mr. Pupkin?!?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 124   INT:   MARSHA'S APARTMENT - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 125   INT:   THE BASEMENT ROOM - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Now are you going to talk to us, or not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure I'll talk. Just get me someone from the show.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to GIARDELLO) Get that Thomas guy in here. GIARDELLO leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We haven't much time, Mr. King. PUPKIN looks towards the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's start with your name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rupert Pupkin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's your real name?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: You an American?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Then why do you people do these things? THOMAS enters.   He scrutinizes PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you on the show?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.   I'm Bert Thomas. PUPKIN pulls thin piece of neatly typewritten paper from his inside jacket and hands it to THOMAS.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Here's the introduction to my act. Please make sure Mr. Randall follows it exactly as I've written it. PATTEN nods to THOMAS who takes the paper and reads it as he leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.   How about helping us, Mr. King?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about make-up?   I need make-up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to PLAINCLOTHESMEN) Put some color in his cheeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MARSHA has finished a half bottle of wine. She is eating a beautifully decorated piece of stuffed capon and talking through her tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (crying) It was the second lead! I'd never gotten a part in my life and here I get the second lead. And what does Daddy say? SHOT of LANGFORD still bound from tip to toe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not "Marsha, that's wonderful" or "we're proud of you" or anything. Oh no. He starts lecturing me on how I should have tried out for Emily! Now do you understand, Jerry! MARSHA gets hold of herself. She swallows a couple of pills and swills them down with some wine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (calmer) My doctor says I shouldn't get excited. MARSHA picks at another piece of capon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the best I ever made it. You want some? LANGFORD, the mummy, nods. MARSHA picks up the plate across from her, fills it with food, and pulls a chair up next to LANGFORD. She undoes the tape around his mouth and picks a sock out of his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now open.   Marsha's going to feed her Jerry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two young GIRLS are working on big cue cards copying from the piece of paper PUPKIN has given THOMAS. TONY RANDALL stands next to THOMAS. The two of them watch. RANDALL is going over the lines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PUPKIN has obviously been worked over.   He is sweating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about it, King?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I'm not on that show, Jerry Langford is dead, I promise you. PATTEN nods to his PLAINCLOTHESMEN again who start working PUPKIN over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The beginning of the taping is seconds away. Everyone is in his place. The STAGE MANAGER is counting down from five on his fingers. At zero, he points across to RICK ROSS, the orchestra leader, who strikes up the familiar Langford Show theme song.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Four TECHNICAL ENGINEERS are seated along a large console containing a multitude of small television screens. One screen shows the spotlight falling where Randall will enter. Another shows the logo of the Langford Show. Another shows nothing in particular. Behind the TECHNICIANS, stand CROCKETT and the EXECUTIVES we have seen in the previous scenes. A TECHNICIAN is giving instructions to the CAMERAMAN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold on two. Hold. Hold.    Come on, Keller. Get it framed!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The theme song is playing.   BERT CANTER stands off-camera at one side of the stage before a microphone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 131   INT:   THE TELEVISION STUDIO - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Now! Direct from New York! It's the Jerry Langford Show with guest host Tony Randall and his special guests -- Olympic swimmer Mark Spitz, pundit Gore Vidal, the one and only Zsa Zsa Gabor and another of Jerry's taped exclusives, an interview with Prince Ranier of Monaco. As always, Rick Ross and the Orchestra and me, Bert Canter. And now ... say hello to Tony!!!!!!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : An APPLAUSE sign flashes like crazy. The AUDIENCE cheers wildly. In the back, we notice a handful of TACTICAL PATROLMEN scattered about. RANDALL strides on stage briskly, accepting the cheers of the crowd with his arms raised. He nods and then his eyes fix on those hastily written outsized cue cards. He reads them with a mixture of professionalism and wry distance, wanting to disown the words without seeming silly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Good evening, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you. Thank you very much. I have some sad news for you. Earlier today, my writing staff was executed in Central Park by the network firing squad so there'll be no sensational Randall monologue this evening. The AUDIENCE cheers derisively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No embarrassing displays of emotion, please. (the AUDIENCE laughs) Instead, we're going to do something a little bit different this evening -- a lot different if you ask me. We're going to give you a glimpse into the future. It isn't often that you can call someone a sure thing in the entertainment business. After all, the verdict is always in your hands. But I think tonight, after you've met my first guest, you'll agree with me that he's destined for greatness -- in one way or another. So will you please give your warmest greeting to the newest King of Comedy, Rupert Pupkin!!!! The music plays. The APPLAUSE sign flashes. The AUDIENCE applauds heartily -- and nobody appears to fill the spotlight at the edge of the wings. The spotlight holds for what seems like an eternity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just hold.   Three. Pick up the audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finally after what seems like an eternity, PUPKIN emerges, straightening his jacket a bit and trying to crane the kinks out of his neck. He is a bit tense but very high and in full command. As he delivers his monologue, PUPKIN is more confident, comfortable and self-assured than we have ever seen him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening, ladies and gentleman. Let me introduce myself. My name is Rupert Pupkin. I was born in Clifton, New Jersey, which was not, at that time, a federal offense. (laughter) Is there anyone here from Clifton? (silence) Good. We can all relax. Now, I'd like to begin by saying that my parents were too poor to afford me a childhood but the fact is nobody is allowed to be really poor in Clifton. Once you fall below eleven thousand you're exiled to Passaic. My parents did, in fact, put down the first two payments on my childhood. Then they tried to return me to the hospital as defective.   But, like everyone else I grew up in large part thanks to my mother. If she was only here today I'd say, "Hey, mom. What are you doing here? You've been dead for nine years?" (laughter) You should have seen my mother. She was wonderful
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : 132   INT:   CONTROL ROOM - NIGHT TECHNICIAN
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 133   INT:   THE STAGE - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: blonde, beautiful, intelligent, alcoholic. (laughter) We used to drink milk together after school. Mine was homogenized. Hers was loaded. (laughter) Once she was picked up for speeding. They clocked her doing fifty
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in our garage. (laughter) When they tested her they found that her alcohol was two per cent blood. They took away her license and she died shortly afterwards. We used to joke together Mom and me, until the tears would stream down her face and she'd throw up. (laughter) And who would clean it up? Not Dad. He was too busy down at O'Grady's throwing up on his own. In fact, until I was sixteen, I thought throwing up was a sign of maturity. While the other kids were off in the woods sneaking cigarettes, I was hiding behind the house with my fingers down my throat. (laughter) I never got anywhere until one day, my father caught me. Just as he was giving me a final kick in the stomach, for luck, I managed to heave all over his new shoes. "That's it," I thought. "I've made it. I'm finally a man!" (laughter) As it turned out, that was the only time my father ever paid any real attention to me. He was usually too busy out in the park playing ball with my sister, Rose. And, today thanks to those many hours of practice, my sister Rose has grown into a fine man. (laughter) Me, I wasn't especially interested in athletics. The only exercise I ever got was when the other kids picked on me. They used to beat me up once a week, usually Tuesday. After a while, the school worked it into the curriculum. And, if you knocked me out, you got extra credit. (laughter) Except there was this one kid who was afraid of me. I kept telling him, "Hit me! Hit me! What's the matter with you? Don't you want graduate?" As for me, I was the only kid in the history of the school to graduate in traction. The school nurse tucked my diploma into my sling. But my only real interest, right from the beginning, was show business. Even as a young man, I began at the very top, collecting autographs. (laughter)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dinner is over. MARSHA is sitting next to LANGFORD. As LANGFORD speaks, it is obvious that he is turning on the charm for strategic reasons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was a wonderful dinner, Marsha. I want you to know how much I enjoyed it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can do it again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to show you my gratitude. But it's a little difficult, like this. LANGFORD indicates his bonds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in a tone of intimacy) Let's say I took all this off.   What would you do to me? Tell me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We break in on a great burst of laughter.      PUPKIN is just finishing his monologue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A lot of you are probably wondering why Jerry couldn't make it this evening. Well, he's tied up -- and I'm the one who tied him. (laughter) You think I'm joking, but that's the only way I could break into show business -- by hijacking Jerry Langford. (laughter) I'm not kidding. Right now, Jerry Langford is strapped to a bedstead somewhere in the middle of this city. (laughter) Go ahead. Laugh. But the fact is ... I'm here. Tomorrow you'll know I wasn't kidding and you'll think I was crazy. But I figured it this way: better to be King for a Night than Schmuck for a Lifetime!!! (laughter) Good night ladies and gentlemen. God bless you. The AUDIENCE applauds heartily. The music plays. And TONY RANDALL salutes PUPKIN with a wave of his hand. PUPKIN goes off stage after soaking up the applause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A group of PLAINCLOTHESMEN seize PUPKIN and march him briskly through the backstage corridor towards the backstage door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A handful of PEOPLE are waiting, among them the autograph hunters, MAE, CELESTE and SIDNEY. MAE, out of a reflex of thirty years, immediately extends her autograph book towards PUPKIN, then, recognizing him, immediately pulls it back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to PUPKIN) Who did you get? PUPKIN says nothing as he is hustled into a limousine. SIDNEY and CELESTE look on. MAE trails after PUPKIN and the PLAINCLOTHESMEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to PLAINCLOTHESMAN) Could I have a ride? The PLAINCLOTHESMAN says nothing and starts getting in the limo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've never been in one. The limo pulls away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PUPKIN stands among a crowd of PLAINCLOTHESMEN who have obviously been working him over. PATTEN sits behind his desk. GIARDELLO is at his side. The clock on the wall reads 10:20.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, Pupkin. We'll start all over again. Where is Langford? You know, we're going to find him sooner or later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm trying to tell    you, Inspector. You let me walk out    of here, right? And as soon as I'm    seen my act on the show -- as soon    as I'm sure they've really put it on --    I'll tell you where Jerry is and you'll    get him back safe and sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine, Pupkin. Then why don't you watch the show here with us? That way we're all happy. (to GIARDELLO) What channel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We get that one in fine.    So what do you say, Pupkin?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I'll say it again.    You let me go now. PATTEN motions to the PLAINCLOTHESMEN wearily with his head. They drag PUPKIN off. PATTEN looks up at the clock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MARSHA is frantically attempting to unwrap LANGFORD. With each pull of the tape, LANGFORD yelps. There is a small tangle of unwrapped tape collecting around LANGFORD's feet and sticking to MARSHA's clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watch my hair!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, baby. We hear the sound of tape ripping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ow!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PUPKIN is hustled before PATTEN again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still nothing. PUPKIN glances at the clock.      It is 11:05.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got to get out of here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not going anywhere, Pupkin. Now, where is he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm telling you, Inspector,    if I don't see that show where I    want to see it, Jerry Langford is dead. My     people have instructions to execute    him unless they hear from me by    midnight. PATTEN glances apprehensively at GIARDELLO.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just where is it you want to watch this show?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LANGFORD is half unwrapped now. The place is covered with yard after yard of tape.   MARSHA is working frantically to finish unwrapping LANGFORD who is helping now that his arms are free.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ow!   God damnit! Not so fast!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (working frantically) We haven't all night, baby. MARSHA rips the tape off LANGFORD.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I love you, baby.   I love you so much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A limo drives down Broadway, followed by an unmarked car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PATTEN and GIARDELLO sit up front, with the DRIVER. PUPKIN sits in the back between two PLAINCLOTHESMEN. The limo pulls up in front of the bar-restaurant where RITA works. PATTEN turns around in the front seat to address PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here we, are, Pupkin. I don't know what this is all about, but as soon as you've seen yourself, you're going to talk to us or I promise you, you'll never see daylight again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll need a couple of minutes, Inspector.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : 134   INT:   MARSHA'S APARTMENT - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 135   INT:   THE TELEVISION STUDIO -- NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 136   INT:   THE WINGS - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 137   EXT:   THE BACKSTAGE DOOR - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 138   INT:   INSPECTOR PATTEN'S DOWNTOWN OFFICE - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 139   INT:   MARSHA'S APARTMENT - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 140   INT:   PATTEN'S OFFICE - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 141   INT:   MARSHA'S APARTMENT - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 142   EXT:   BROADWAY - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 143   INT:   THE LIMO - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?!?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: After it's over, I want a couple of minutes. And I'll need ten dollars. Does anyone of you gentlemen have my wallet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't push me, Pupkin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A condemned man's last request, Inspector.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'll tell you right away, the answer is no, Pupkin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not much of a ransom, Inspector ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (losing his temper) Look, I'm drawing the line, that's all! No ten dollars and that's it. (emphatically) No -- ten -- dollars!!!! You understand?!?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in mollifying tones) Sure. Sure, Inspector. No ten dollars ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (appeased) Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... and no Jerry Langford. There is a pause as PATTEN stifles himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, it's getting late, Inspector.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (exploding to     one of his MEN) Go ahead. Give him      his goddamned ten dollars! Give him      twenty! I don't care. Just get him      out of here! One of the PLAINCLOTHESMEN in the back opens the door and PUPKIN and the other PLAINCLOTHESMAN get out. The unmarked car has pulled up behind the limo and other PLAINCLOTHESMEN stand next to it. PUPKIN and the two PLAINCLOTHESMEN start walking the ten yards or so to the bar-restaurant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PUPKIN marches in flanked by the PLAINCLOTHESMEN. The clock over the bar reads 11:30. RITA looks up from talking with a CUSTOMER and sees PUPKIN. She says nothing. She just looks at him. There are five CUSTOMERS at the bar. A working class COUPLE in their late fifties are half-stewed, the man telling the woman that her friend, Maud, isn't really her friend because she wants $150 for a used refrigerator. A few seats down, two MEN in their mid- forties, in wind-breakers are locked in an intense but inaudible conversation. And, close to the television set which hangs over the far end of the bar sits a MOUSY MAN with glasses, who looks like an accountant. He is sipping a beer, his eyes fixed on the set where the CBS late movie is just showing its logo. PUPKIN marches up to the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (urgently to RITA) Turn on Langford. Seven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey!   I'm watching this . RITA keeps staring at PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just turn it. Come on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was here first, mister. You can't just walk in like this. It isn't fair. RITA glances at the MAN. PUPKIN can't      wait. He vaults onto the bar and turns the set to the     Langford Show, just as, on screen, he walks from the wings     onto the stage to the applause of the studio audience.      Perched atop the bar, standing next to the image of himself,     PUPKIN looks down at RITA, a smile of pride and triumph on     his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PUPKIN walking onto television screens in various homes across America -- in a chic New York living room, in a suburban bedroom, in the parlor of an Indiana farmhouse, in a kitchen where a COUPLE is in the middle of a raging domestic quarrel, in an otherwise dark bedroom where a COUPLE is in the throes of lovemaking, in a bar, a station house, in a television store window display.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MARSHA has just removed her dress and stands in      her bra and panties as LANGFORD unwraps the last tape from      about his ankles. The room is swimming in tape, like an       enormous boa constrictor gone mad. MARSHA moves towards       LANGFORD, her arms open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, baby.   Baby. LANGFORD frees his ankles of tape just in time to side-step MARSHA and moves quickly to the dining room table where he grabs the gun. He trains it on her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop! MARSHA moves toward him. He pulls the trigger, releasing a plastic pellet that hits MARSHA in the stomach, stinging her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ow! LANGFORD glances down in horror at the gun which he now realizes is a toy and looks up in horror to see MARSHA, bigger than life, bearing down on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be afraid of Marsha, baby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CUSTOMERS are watching the conclusion of Pupkin's monologue, along with the PLAINCLOTHESMEN and PUPKIN. WE COME IN a split second after a joke. The CUSTOMERS laugh, with the exception of the MOUSY MAN who is waiting, in bad humor, for Pupkin's act to finish. The PLAINCLOTHESMEN laugh reluctantly. PUPKIN, no longer standing on the bar, but back down with the others, watches with fascination. RITA watches grimly, occasionally glancing at PUPKIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I figured it this way: better to be King for a Night than Schmuck for a Lifetime. (audience and CUSTOMERS laugh)   Good night, ladies and gentlemen, and God bless you. The television audience applauds and the CUSTOMERS applaud and cheer in good humor except for the MOUSY MAN. The HALF-STEWED MAN leans across his WOMAN to yell at PUPKIN as the two FRIENDS in windbreakers congratulate PUPKIN at the same time. There is a brief moment of carnival excitement.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : 144   INT:   THE BAR-RESTAURANT - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 145   MONTAGE -- NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 146   INT:   MARSHA'S APARTMENT -- NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 147   INT:   BAR-RESTAURANT - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: on TV
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hey, that's pretty good.             (to PUPKIN) Schmuck for a Lifetime!      How do you think up all (to the WOMAN) You know      that stuff? who he's talkin' about? Your brother!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a trick, that's What about your all. Larry can do it brother?                as good as him. HALF-STEWED MAN        MOUSY MAN What about him?              Is it over now? HALF-STEWED WOMAN             FIRST FRIEND He's another one.       He's funnier than Larry. Larry just makes a lot HALF-STEWED MAN of faces. (getting a little angry) I told you to shut up about
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: my brother. (to PUPKIN)       Well, if nobody She doesn't know nuthin'.     minds ... PUPKIN takes all this praise and excitement with a shy smile of satisfaction, glancing at RITA from time to time for her reaction. She merely stares at PUPKIN with a sad expression on her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Rita. Don't spoil the party. (to the CUSTOMERS) Drinks all around on me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in a loud voice, to HALF- STEWED WOMAN) What about the hundred and fifty? We never saw a penny outta your brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's because my brother is a family man , not like Phil. The argument between the HALF-STEWED MAN and his WOMAN continues at the end of the bar. The two FRIENDS have resumed their intense conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the two FRIENDS) What'll you have? FIRST FRIEND I'm okay.   Thanks, pal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me, too. The MOUSY MAN has climbed up on the bar and has turned the TV back to the late movie. He sits enthralled by a scene of violence courtesy of Tony Curtis as the Boston Strangler. PUPKIN looks down the bar at the STEWED COUPLE to offer them drinks, but they are lost in an argument over the relative merits of their brothers. PUPKIN turns to the PLAINCLOTHESMEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't suppose you're allowed anything. (to RITA) I guess nobody's in a celebrating mood. How about you? You want something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's getting time, Pupkin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a second.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in a sad, serious voice to PUPKIN) That was true, wasn't it? ... about the kidnapping. PUPKIN nods and shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now you can say you knew me.   That's something, anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Pupkin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to RITA, in a quiet, tender voice) I guess I've got go. Take care of yourself, will you. And when you're bored -- you know, when you're brushing your teeth or something, give me a thought, okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. The PLAINCLOTHESMEN lead PUPKIN out of the bar. The two FRIENDS are still buried in their intense, private conversation. The PLAINCLOTHESMEN and PUPKIN walk past the HALF-STEWED COUPLE.
direction.name: direction
